description: You gotta love a legitimate tea place.  I walked in and said my ailments and she (Ying) told me which tea would work for me and the benefits.  I asked for some sugar or honey. She said NOPE this is a traditional real place. She said you need the taste the full flavor of the tea. I got a cup of the bitter tea. It taste very bitter but my cough seems to have settled down. She also gave us some information about the Pur Eh tea and why she enjoyed that tea.  We had a sample it was very nice. If I lived in this area I would be a regular at this place.
author: Tae S.

description:
This place is amazing! 
I found out about this place because of a video Tasty posted on Facebook. 
Jenny helped me out today and has great customer service. She asked what type of teas I'm used to and then suggested some and let me taste them. 

There were other people there so whatever they wanted to taste she also let me taste. If she's doing a pot of tea why not let everyone taste lol. Awesome. She's very knowledgeable regarding the teas. 
I loved it here. I want to show it off to everyone. The teas are the best around. Very worth your money. 
Sorry I didn't tip you Jenny, next time I'll make sure to take enough money.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I thought this would be one of those intimidating places where the proprietor would try to explain the finer nuances of various tea leaves to which I would respond with a glazed stare. But no, the most intimidating part of the shop is the over 150 varieties of tea on display in various canisters with photos on their descriptive labels, most literal translations and others comically tongue-in-cheek. Jamie W. and I came here after stopping to smell the roses and whatever flora they have at the San Francisco Botanical Garden. The high praise on Yelp lured us in on a slow Saturday afternoon when we had the full attention of the very young staff (photo: http://bit.ly/2eDdrH8).

There was no sighting of owner Haymen Da Luz, whom I heard was quite the colorful connoisseur, but his staff did him proud with their thorough descriptions and obliging behavior during our generous tea tasting. The selection covered the full range of loose leaf teas - jasmine, white, green oolong, black, pu-erh. We went for the sweeter ones like Chocolate Mint and Peach Momo White Tea (photo: http://bit.ly/2uKhQ12) before settling on a purchase of the Coconut Green Tea which was deliciously Mounds-like in flavor (photo: http://bit.ly/2ukLiZh). There were all kinds of tea accessories available including little clay pots and gaiwan sets (photo: http://bit.ly/2tPiOF9). It's definitely worth a return visit to get a further education on the joys of tea.

TEA - 4 stars...really subtle flavors that linger in the palate
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...cute little space packed with quality...love how they explain they don't sell boba because their teas don't suck balls
SERVICE - 4 stars...informative and attentive
TOTAL - 4 stars...really a treat on a quiet afternoon if you don't overstay your welcome
author: Ed U.

description:
*** In Short ***

Long-time neighborhood shop offering an extensive array and knowledge of teas.

*** In Depth ***

Having eaten in the area many times over the years, I've seen and passed by Aroma countless times, but never actually gone in. Not that I have a dislike of tea: far from it! But it was only until recently, learning that tea *wasn't* the cause of my teeth stains, that I started getting back into it. And what better way than to stock up on loose leaf teas?!

Stopping in one day after lunch nearby, my friend and I sat down to a (free!) tea tasting session with the surprisingly hip and hilarious owner of the shop, sampling almost a dozen varietals, and learning quite a bit about the origins and differences during that process.

With so many teas available, ranging all across the quality spectrum, it can definitely be hard to choose, but they help find tea samples that meet your particular interests. That said, even that can be a little off, as I didn't like most of the initial teas enough to commit, only coming across a couple at the very end of my tasting session. Part of the reason for this is probably due to them brewing a much stronger tea than I myself prefer, so keep that in mind while taste testing.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Not very large, but very spacious, with just the single counter in the back for the register and tea tasting, so accessibility shouldn't be too big an issue.

Bathroom - Don't think they actually have a public one.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Aroma Tea Shop on 6th is - in this Yelpist's humble opinion - a national treasure.  Truly exceptional customer service combined with an extensive and high quality selection of teas make for an unforgettable experience.  Whether you are a tea connoisseur or just a casual sipper, your visit to Aroma Tea Shop will make you smarter and your day better.

Tucked away on 6th, right off of the hustle and bustle of Clement, is the wide-windowed, yellow canopied storefront that can best be described as being to tea what the Library of Alexandria was to books prior to its tragic immolation.  This tiny storefront contains a magnificent collection of the finest and most desirable cured leaves of Camilia Senensis.

The store, as one of the owners Haymen kindly explained to me upon one visit, is set up in many ways like a modern dispensary.  Canisters of tea and a small selection of brewing and drinking-ware line the walls of this tiny tea shop.  The centerpiece of the store is a tasting bar, where up to four people can comfortably sit and sample teas of their choice or, better yet, teas recommended by whoever is working.

Your dialogue with the host over tiny steaming cups of freshly brewed tea is the real heart and soul of the Aroma Tea Shop experience.  No matter who your host is, they are going to know everything you could possibly want to know about all of the available varieties, and they are more than happy to share this wealth of knowledge with anyone who cares to inquire.  

It's basically like going to a bar, except your bartender is serving you free samples of finely aged Scotch from his private reserves, which he picked up during his latest trip to Scotland, and telling you all about it.  And instead of getting wasted, you are being uplifted by the soothing smells and flavors of teas of all varieties.  Time flies as your senses are stimulated and your mind expanded by taste after taste of Aroma Tea Shop's carefully cultivated selection.

My recommendation is that you go when you've got time to kill.  I've easily ended up spending 45 minutes to an hour there every time I have gone, shooting the breeze, sipping brews, and educating myself one of the world's oldest and most popular beverages.  

Be sure to buy a couple ounces and tip your host a dollar or two for providing a 5 star experience.  These people are experts without the snobbery, and their product is of the highest quality.
author: Max T.

description: Had a great time today at this place. Very educational tea tasting, the couple that was attending to us were the owners of the shop and they were very nice.
author: Maries M.

description: Haymen was a wonderful tea host, I didn't realize how much goes into the tea process, oxidation, drying / firing, its wonderfully interesting and greatly enjoyed the tea tasting he gave, pu-er was very interesting, tasted better then it smelled say the least, the mi xiang honey was one of my favorites also supreme zheng. So many choices and haymens passion and personality is enough in itself to return. Sadly I live on the east coast, plus side I can order online with FREE SHIPPING
author: Arjuna P.

description: Free tea tasting? Hands down best tea shop in the city the owner is very knowledgeable and an expert when it comes to the teas. Whenever I'm in the clement area I always take a second to visit the tea shop. During my visit I usually get offered a teacup sample of a different tea. blue people tea is my favorite and is a must try when visiting. They also have a variety of tea sets and tools. I love that you can buy the loose leaf teas by the weight, I always make jokes about buying an  1/8th of loose leaf when visiting (I work with cannabis)
author: Jeany Z.

description: This amazing tea shop is a gem. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit with the proprietor who was quite knowledge and friendly. We sampled many delicious teas and left with about 8 different kinds. Highly recommended.
author: Kim C.

description: By far my favorite tea shop ever! I touted their expertise and selection even while living in LA. They have become more commercialized (not in a bad way) since my last visit several years ago and offer more sample boxes and packs to try the tea. They still have a great selection of ceramic teapots and a variety of fancy Chinese teas. It's very easy to get carried away and spend a lot of money on TV, which I do way too often. I'm assuming that young man is still the owner, although I didn't see him during this trip, he's very knowledgeable and informative about Tea. It's in lightning to hear what he has to say about the different blends and varieties there are. Treat yourself if you have time to do a tea tasting as well
author: Jennifer L.

description: This is a really fantastic tea shop, decently priced and Hayman really knows his stuff. They're constantly brewing tea so you really get a feel for what you're getting (and might find a few you didn't know you needed!) love it
author: Angela R.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place. They have some really good tea, for sure, but the tasting experience when I went two weeks ago was a huge let down compared to when I went a few years ago.

The first time I went, I was seated at a little table in the back and treated to a lovely tasting and explanation of a bunch of different teas - definitely one of my favorite experiences in Chinatown. We liked it so much that we bought a bunch of fairly expensive (but delicious) tea, and even hung their business card up in our kitchen to remember to go back.

However, the most recent time I was there, the experience was totally the opposite: I felt rushed, like they didn't want us there (we were the only customers on a sunny Sunday afternoon), and the lady was brusque and not friendly. However, we did (awkwardly) still sample and buy some tea. I love the mix-and-match bags, where you can buy a little bit of a bunch of different teas. They had a 5-for-$20 deal. And it's really yummy tea!
author: Liz F.

description:
Wow!  What an amazing little place! I came here through Yelp to do a tasting of many different teas.  They were all amazing.  I had a bit of a Bubba Forest Gump moment--peach tea, coconut tea, green tea, blue tea, white tea...  The flavors and aromas were truly wonderful.  All of the flavors were so complex and fresh-tasting.  I've never seen nor tasted so many different blends.  I love tea, but I had never had tea taste so special.  Their tea is a real experience, not to mention the hilarious pictures on the loose leaf tea jars and super funny sayings on the wall.  This is a place for what I would call "gifting tea."   They are high-end, top quality teas that feel like a special occasion.  In short, if you're broke, keep right on walking.  This is deep pocket tea, for sure.  It was a bit rich for my blood, but I could certainly taste a pronounced difference in quality.  

The owners go to China to source their teas themselves, and they are always looking for unique blends.  The teas are mostly loose leaf and in a state where you can actually identify what's in their blends.  I loved everything we tried, but the coconut tea really stands out as something memorable and unique. Honestly, all of the teas were very much memorable for me, and they turned my idea of tea on its head.  The owner who did our tea testing was funny and cool and gave us interesting tidbits about the ingredients, sourcing, and flavor profile of each tea.  It was so nice to have so much knowledge about what we were enjoying in our cups.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Visited this shop during a stay a few years ago. BEST DAY EVER. Sat with the owner and his friend and sampled 50+ teas. Told him what type I like and he found me two new favorites. Left so satisfied and such a fun experience!

Fast forward two years and I'm out of tea. I see they have a holiday discount online and fill my cart. I wait too long, the code expires. I email and they reinstate it for me! I paid for standard shipping, and they rush shipped it anyway. Such good customer service and as always, the teas speak for themselves. 

Gave two tea sets as gifts and both recipients are over the moon. I cannot recommend this shop in person or online enough!
author: Stacy M.

description:
Aroma Tea Shop is the place for Asian tea aficionados. It's appropriately located just off Clement Street (San Francisco's other Chinatown) on 6th Avenue. There's a second location in Chinatown. Thanks to Jessica T for introducing us to this place. I've been up and down Clement many times, but haven't explored several of its side streets. This is a unique find and it's been in business since 2005.

Aroma Tea Shop's Richmond store amounts to a single room filled with over 150 teas. I believe most of these are loose leaf, stored in canisters. For regular folks, the selection can be overwhelming. The main wall has five shelves filled to the brim. Each shelf contains 24 canisters, tightly lined up. The back wall has an additional three shelves containing about 40 additional canisters. The outside of each canister has an enlarged photo of the actual tea leaves, the food it may taste like, or a humorous picture or graphic.

For example, the "Really Fresh Lemongrass" tea is represented by a photo of lemongrass, the Cherry Rose Sencha tea is represented by a photo of cherries, and the Muscat Grape Oolong tea is represented by a photo of grapes and wine. Playful examples include the "8 Immorals" oolong tea sporting the Super 8 Motel graphic, the Yunnan Kung Fu Black Tea using the pixel cover art from the 8-bit Nintendo game Kung Fu, the "Super Russian Caravan" black tea using art from Communist Russia, and the popular "Blue People King Grade" tea featuring a photo of blue-shirted Best Buy employees.

Most of the teas are sold in 4-ounce increments, though I did see some selling in 2-ounce increments. Tea types include white, green, black, oolong, jasmine, herbal, and pu-erh. Pu-erh tea is an aged and fermented dark tea from the Yunnan province in China. Each tea canister is displayed with a small, helpful information card with details on taste and country of origin. I think most of the teas come from China, Taiwan, and Japan. I did see one from France. Prices run the gamut from $9 to $120 (!) for 4 ounces.

This is a family-run business headed by the husband-wife duo of Haymen Da Luz and Ying Wu. They make trips to Asia to personally pick which teas to bring back. On a wall inside the shop, there's a giant photo of them at one of the tea leaf farms in Taiwan. There are photos of their two kids too. It's a humble, unpretentious business, unlike some hipster coffee bars or highfalutin gourmet tea retailers.

"Tea Man" Haymen is quite the showman. He's a genuinely funny guy and seems skilled at his craft and very knowledgeable about tea. He and his wife regularly conduct free tea tastings at their special custom-built tasting counter. Haymen hosted our group's tea tasting where we sampled the Coconut Paradise green tea, the Muscat Grape oolong tea, the Meng Hai Big Leaf (1990) pu-erh tea, and the Blue People King Grade tea. He walked us through the flavors from earthy and roasted to sweet and fruity. The flavor profiles were distinctively different. I've never tasted such a wide range of teas in one sitting. The tasting reminded me of the coffee taster's flavor wheel (there's one for tea tasters too).

About 10 teas are available hot or iced to go for $3.50 each. These include Muscat Oolong, Peach White Tea, Jasmine Milk Tea, and Hella Strong Chai (haha). You know it's from San Francisco when it has the word "hella" in it. In addition to tea leaves and ready-to-drink tea beverages, Aroma Tea Shop also carries tea pots, cups, trays, filters/strainers, bottles, and other various tea-related accessories.

While I'm no tea expert (I'm just a bubble tea simpleton), I can appreciate the sheer variety of fine teas offered at this shop and recommend to anyone who happens to be visiting the neighborhood swing by for a free tasting. You'll probably learn something new and, who knows, perhaps find a new tea to take home.
author: Daniel B.

description: Fantastic tea shop if you're looking for loose leaf tea to go or something to drink on the spot. The employee helping our {large} group was extremely accommodating to letting us sample a variety of tea options including things we were curious about and her own recommendations. Just take a seat at the tea bar and may your journey into tea knowledge begin. NOTE: the shop currently have construction out front, but they're still open. Make sure you spend some time looking at all the signs in the shop, quiet quirky and they're sure to make you chuckle. Plus, take note of all the teas they have in stock, some for specified 'issues' others for the sophisticated tea drinker and others yet just for enjoyment. As far as inviting, friendly, Chinese tea shops, Aroma Tea Shop is as good as it gets.
author: Rose L.

description:
During our last day together on the 2015 Acronym Summit weekend Jessica T. and Collen B. took us on a lovely walk around a few different San Francisco neighborhoods. In the span of a few hours we ate a wonderful meal, checked out some beautiful scenery, and found some amazing little stores. Of all the places we visited that day (and there were many!) Aroma Tea Shop was by far my favorite!

Aroma is a family ran business. I love that about them. The husband and wife team who were running the store were both very helpful and funny (the guy cracked me up, his wife was a little more on the reserved side; they balanced eachother out nicely). Our group was happily treated to many different samples of tea; ranging from muddy to fruit-tasting. There were tons of tea containers lining the walls and we were asked if we would like to sample different ones. During the entire sampling experience we were treated to jokes, the history of tea, and explanations of both what the tea does to/for you (health benefits) and price points. Furthermore, the man running the store explained how they make trips to China and Taiwan to visit the tea farms themselves so that they know they are importing the best quality of tea leaves. 

You can buy tea by the ounce to take home, choose from many different types of prepackaged tea leafs, or treat yourself to a  hot or iced tea drink of your choice (per the hillarious sign don't expect boba). I didn't purchase a drink but several members of the group did; some for flavor and other to cure ailments (ie a tummy ache, which they said later on the tea really helped). They also have boxed and wrapped gift sets that you can purchase that would make a wonderful gift for someone who really enjoyed tea. 

Aroma was by far one of my favorite places to visit on my weekend trip to San Francisco. The customer service was stellar, and something that I think more businesses should strive to model themselves after. Throughout all the information that was shared to us I felt like there was no pressure at all to purchase anything, and I really respect that. Although I don't see any trips to San Francisco for myself in the near future Aroma is definitely somewhere that I would recommend both visitors and locals check out. 


[Note: there is street parking, and also a small parking area on the curb a few buildings down].
author: Zoie H.

description:
My first ever tea tasting experience was here at Aroma Tea Shop in the Richmond district in SF. I never knew such a thing existed, as none of the tea shops in my hometown offer this kind of experience.  Pull up a chair and get ready to experience some really great tasting teas.  I'm not a tea connoisseur by any means, but even as a novice tea drinker, I could taste the difference between tea from a bag and the tea offered at this tea shop. 

Yes, the tea here is more expensive, but quality matters, and at least you can sample the tea before you buy it, so you're assured that you're spending your hard earned dollars on something you like.

In addition to loose leaf teas, they also sell hot and cold tea based beverages. But much to my dismay, they don't sell their tea drinks with boba. :)
author: Nat N.

description:
Had some issues ordering on their website via PayPal but the owner fixed the issue asap. Not only did he take money off the order, but overnighted my tea. Huge plus. I always recommended this shop before but now I'll have to advocate their customer service even more as well. 

Cheers

-Jason
author: Jason G.

description: Stopped in here to for the first time ever to buy some milk oolong and the counter person was in the middle of doing a tea tasting for a bunch of white dudebros. She was talking about the puerh like it was some kind of frat house challenge -- like "Oooh! This one is super stinky." She was also totally ignoring me & not making eye contact, so after waiting by the register for a few minutes I just left. I honestly do not feel the urge to ever come back - felt like a total tourist trap.
author: Hawley S.

description:
When we shop for tea, we always head straight for Aroma Tea Shop.  Locally owned and operated, this place is perfect for my hubby (a tea connoisseur) as well as my 15 year old nephew (visiting me and curious about all things San Francisco).  The host is usually the owner, Hayman.  He loves sitting down and sharing his free tastings with costumers.  

I brought a newbie with me on my last visit and Hayman patiently explained the differences between white, green and black tea all the while making us laugh with his sarcastic, silly puns.  

He visits Tawaiin and China twice a year to bring back fresh harvests of leaves.  This is a great place to bring friends.  We usually stop at the used bookstore, Green Apple Books, across the street after our tea tasting and make a fun afternoon out of it.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
My favorite place to buy, taste and enjoy tea!
The proprietor is funny and wonderful. He quickly learns your tea preferences and makes fabulous suggestions. I particularly enjoy his range of oolong teas and tea pots. 
He ships all over the US too!
author: Midori M.

description: Nothing short of fantastic.  I've been through different tea spots all over the Bay Area, and this by far is my absolute favorite. The owner takes the time to show you all the complete flavor profile of each tea - from the way it was cultivated, to the texture, and the taste differences from each pouring. If you're the type that thinks of tea as Lipton or Earl Grey, then this place will open your eyes (as with other tea spots, but this in particular with their quality). He knows his stuff, and is very tea geek friendly.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Great selection of teas, and the girl that helped us was extremely knowledgeable.  I bought an Yixing clay tea pot and several teas, can't wait to use it.
author: Anne S.

description:
An experience for sure. 

I left here discovering I have an obsession with Coconut Green Tea. It's absolutely refreshing and delicious iced or hot but I preferred Iced!

The walls are lined with tea and tea items. You can sample any flavor, just ask!

You can get a cup to enjoy there or to go in addition to taking tea leaves home to enjoy them yourself.

It was a very cool experience to watch the owner make the samples, school everyone on tea, and hear about his history. His wife was assisting him as well and she was very sweet! 

Definitely an experience to check out!
author: Colleen B.

description: Very friendly people and highly knowledgeable about tea! They can answer just about any questions about tea. :) Since moving out of San Francisco, it's been hard to get more tea from them but I'm so glad they sell online now! I just received my order with record timing (a little over 24 hours with free shipping?!) thanks so much they are amazing quality as always!
author: Julie M.

description:
Our stop at Aroma turned out to be a really pleasant surprise. I drink tea pretty regularly but I typically drink the Lipton tea bags that I grew up drinking (though I know lean more towards the green tea over the black). I've stopped into my local Teavana but found the experience overwhelming and awkward. When we walked into Aroma, my first thought was of Teavana because of the rows and rows of various types of tea. I realized very quickly that I was way off the mark.

The signage around the store is so funny and the whole experience was the opposite of the ostentatious staff you tend to have at a Teavana. The names and descriptions and pictures on the containers are super funny (everyone from the President to a group of Best Buy employees is featured). The owner told us that he goes back to China a couple of times a year to pick up the tea and let us try quite a few different types. It was a warm day so I got one of their iced green teas and it was great. 

It's not cheap but the quality of the tea is evident with each taste. If you want cheap tea, you can easily find it at the grocery store but if you want something of a high quality that comes along with a fun experience, check out Aroma.
author: Kristina K.

description:
The place that originally got me hooked on tea deserves an update (5 stars, again... naturally). As a refresher, Aroma is a small but powerful tea shop on 6th Avenue in the Richmond, known for its excellent customer service and complimentary, super-educational tea tastings. It's been a while since I lived in the neighborhood, but I still make the trek here about twice a year to stock up on my faves and try something new.

To be sure, this place is quite the mecca for tea snobs, and not necessarily cheap depending on the volume of tea you buy. But with the option of picking out easily-labeled, pre-packaged teas and/or small amounts of even the highest-quality ish, the store is still geared towards the everyday, casual tea drinker. And the tea tastings are still so fun. We almost always get Haymen, who has an amazing deadpan sense of humor (not to mention is an expert in the tea biz).

Here's what I picked up during my latest visit:

~ Premium Dragon Well, a Chinese green tea (tried and true)
~ Jin Jun Mei Golden Thread, a unique black tea (sampled and convinced)
~ The lavender combo, i.e. herbal tea mix of rosebuds, lavender, and osmanthus flower, pre-packed into individual servings (my go-to at bedtime)
~ White pu-erh, half an ounce (yes, they are still throwing in those complimentary samples that I mentioned 6 years ago)

Best of SF, no doubt. Be back in 6-ish months!
author: Kate V.

description: A few days ago, I left work early to go to this shop. Their website and Yelp list their closing time as 7 p.m. When I arrived at 6:30, they were already closed. A couple days later I called to ask what time they close. They said 6 p.m. So I left work early again and got to the shop at 5:20, only to find them closed again. It's very disrespectful to waste people's time by telling them you'll be open when you're not.
author: Jacob R.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed them before. 

This is a beautiful friendly locally owned tea shop which is totally legit.  Plus, even if you are a tea novice, they will let you sample all different teas, they don't judge, and they are super patient.  

Sometimes I come in and the wife is in charge, and sometimes it's the husband.  Both are totally knowledgeable, and friendly.  For me, tea is the new wine.  So much to learn!  I feel so lucky to have this tea store in my neighborhood so I can sample everything over the next decade or so!!

I can't really add anything new to their 5 star review status, but I thought I'd throw my 5 stars in the bucket to help support this amazing business!
author: Melinda A.

description:
Wonderful selection of teas!..but I think the real treasure here is Haymen, the owner.  He is incredibly helpful and dishes out said help with wit and an enjoyably sarcastic spirit.

Aroma Tea Shop has a large selection of teas.  You pay by the ounce.  This is nice if you want to try several teas, but can also get pricey in a hurry if you're not keeping track in your head or not good at keeping track (ie. 5th grade math skills in real-life application.)

If you aren't sure where to start or just want a quick sample you can also sit at the bar for a nominal fee and taste several items...the fee will even be waived if you end up purchasing enough tea.  You can even put Haymen on the spot and ask for something in your flavor profile...tea that reminds you of an IPA you ask, no problem, here you go.  The tasting bar is a great way to find wonderful selections like:
Blue People King Oolong
Supreme Honey Orchid Oolong
Jasmine Phoenix Eyes White
Yunnan Silver Needle White
author: David V.

description:
I've been coming to Aroma Tea Shop for years, more specifically 7+ years. I found the shop one day just walking around Clement street. 

There are a couple ways you can shop here: 
1. Straight Forward - Come in, pick out your tea, they bag it, you pay and go.
2. Like a Bar - Come in, sit and enjoy a tea tasting of various teas, hang out, buy what you need, and go at your leisure. 

I highly suggest #2. 
The owners of the shop are very informative and interactive during the tea tasting. 

I usually buy White Jasmine Pearl Tea, the herbal tea, and occasionally their high-end specialty teas. 

They also offer tea by the cup if you would like one to-go!
author: Debbie N.

description:
I wandered into The Aroma Tea Shop on the advice of my Chinese Medicine Professor- they mix their own unique blends of teas that you cannot find anywhere else so it was highly recommended for medicinal purposes.    The delightful surprise aside from the incredible array of teas and blends is Haymen the owner - he is a super star & his passion for teas contagious.   Get ready to be thoroughly entertained if he is at the shop, I always leave knowing THAT much more about teas- he is like a wine connoisseur but of teas pointing out the "buttery taste of this Oolong" or the "chocolatey finish to that Black tea".   
First thing Haymen does is pour you a glass of tea that happens to suit his fancy on that particular day which is a great way to start the tea lesson Grasshopper !
I love his customer service and that he always sends me home with samples - he is very generous in that way and of course I always buy more than expected whenever I am there as a result.  That kind of customer service is refreshing & so hard to find these days. Honestly I knew nothing about teas and rituals and now I am turning into an avid student.  One of the most enchanting things Haymen told me was how musicians in China go to the tea fields to play the Guzheng instrument (a flat harpsichord which is the National instrument of China) to make the tea plants happy - that particular blend of tea is the Fujian Black tea (Zheng Shan Xiao Zhong) in case you want to taste what happy plants feel like.   
Another incredible thing I did not know is that ALL tea; Greens, Oolongs, PuErhs, Blacks, etc ALL come from the Camellia plant ! He also showed me pictures of 1000 year old tea trees (the bush turns into trees when they are that old) .  What separates the different types of teas is the processes of oxidation, drying or firing, rolling or withering as well as where the leaf is picked from in the plant (whether it is a bud or longer leaf) - AMAZING. I told my Mom this who is Chinese and she refused to believe me. 

I will admit the experience is not the same if Haymen is not there-no one rushes to offer you samples or cares about your experience - when I mentioned it this to him he explained that the girl who covers for him is his wife's family so essentially he is stuck with her (hilarious !)  
 I haven't had the same luck with the Chinatown location where I can tell they deal with a lot of tourists who probably just come in for free samples but I have never gotten the chance to meet Haymen's wife someone else was there the time I went.  Also, I hope they reprint the information flyer they used to give you with all the medicinal information about the teas including the five element chart so fundamental to Chinese medicine.   I suggest unless you know exactly what you want to call ahead  to make sure Haymen is there - he is what makes the place that much extra cool !
author: NancyChurro C.

description:
There's a reason why this tea shop is so highly rated on Yelp. It's the combination of friendly and knowledgeable service, and immense selection of loose leaf teas. 

For a few bucks, you can pony up to the "bar" and try a variety of teas. Not only that, but the owner is such a wealth of knowledge. 

Add a visit to the Green Apple Books and you'll have a lovely day in Richmond.
author: McKenzie S.

description: My fave: The muscat grape oolong tea was so sweet and delicious. Plus, those actual flavors were subtle yet easily discernible. Hayden allowed us to taste several teas and helped us to appreciate the different varieties. They have literally hundreds of great offerings. Why didn't I discover this hidden treasure when I lived in San Francisco? If you're a tea aficionado them this is THE PLACE to come for your fix. Cheers!
author: Tamia G.

description:
They have a nice selection of teas, and its great that they let you try them on the spot.  That alone gets +2 stars.  However, compared to most other places I buy lose-leaf tea the prices are ludicrously expensive, to the tune of 2x-4x more per oz than at other stores I've shopped at in SF.

They also refused to sell less than 2oz of tea from each bin.  This is a killer, as I want to grab a bunch of different teas to try at home, so that I can find the ones I like most.  A quick taste at the shop is ok but it only steeps for a few second as opposed to minutes at home, and a taste I might enjoy initially can end up being something I dislike after having it a few times.

Overall, if the prices werent so crazy I would probably come back.  As things stand the only reason I would ever come here would be to try some tea's out.
author: Andrew L.

description:
The best, most welcoming, and least pretentious shop with legit tea in the whole city.

Free and entertaining tastings from the owner of this family-run operation who is knowledgeable and funny and they do the tea sourcing themselves. It helps to know what you're after, though, because his selection spans all the way from blends and flavored stuff to pricey and pure serious teas.
author: Austin M.

description: I finally found my coconut green tea!!!!! I discovered coconut green tea couple of years ago from a cafe.  Since then I've looked for it and didn't realize how elusive it was.  I've tried some but it's mixed with other stuff like lemongrass and stuff.  NO I want green tea with just coconut flavor.  Ok I did look for it online but I was shocked with how much it was so I hesitated.  This shop has been on my bookmark and I finally had a chance to go recently.  Lots of options but I came here for my green tea.  Yes it was pricey but when you want good quality, u gotta pay a good price.  4 oz for coconut green tea for $22 and that's the minimum you gotta get it here.  I got it and I'm one happy girl.  Support small local places.
author: Claire J.

description:
Conveniently located in close proximity to Green Apple Books, I can't think of a better way to round out a leisurely rainy day book browse than with hot tea from Aroma Tea Shop.  Free tea tastings and a friendly proprietor who knows his leaves make for a gorgeous Saturday morning experience.  I was able to sample a few different types before settling on their Muscat Oolong (a compelling combination of oolong tea and dried muscat raisins).  The tea was light and aromatic with the loveliest hint of fine wine flavor.  There was also a ginger oolong that was amazing.  At $3 for an ample (20oz, I think?) cup of high quality tea--you can't go wrong.

Get to it!
author: Ophelia M.

description:
I love the tea at the Boba Guys slow bar. Seriously love the tea there. Specifically the Duke of Earl Grey and the Muscat Oolong. I love Earl Grey and this was the best I've had. So bummed they didn't carry the loose leaf tea but then I was told that they got their tea from a place in the Richmond. Didn't take much research on Yelp to figure out that it was Aroma Tea. Didn't take long before I made the trek out there to get some myself.

The guy running the shop is super friendly and he really knows the teas and preparation. I think my Chinese mom would approve. There's a large selection of fancy black and green teas from Asia as well as some flavored teas and "healthy" teas. You can try anything, in fact, they'll keep asking if you want to try so you might as well. 

I only got the Earl Grey and Muscat Oolong - for now. The pricing is per 4 oz but that's a lot of tea. You can get just a 2 oz bag instead (enough to fill up a jam jar for Earl Grey, much more for the Muscat Oolong). $25 for the two. Probably not worth it unless you're into high quality whole leaf teas. I am. Totally worth it.

Can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Jean K.

description:
The married couple that owns this place travels abroad to hand-pick tea leaves and bring them back to the shop. If you love loose leaf tea and are looking to try some new varieties of black, green, white, oolong, and other teas, you will love it here. The owner was very patient in letting us sample 6 or 7 different types and answering all of our questions. And he knows a ton about this stuff. 

The teas are not inexpensive, but the prices are fair considering the quality, rarity, and number of infusions you will get with most of these leaves.
author: F. J.

description: Best traditional and gourmet tea flavor mashups.  They offer free tea tastings/education at their tea bar!! Haymen is fun and engaging w his interesting personality and charm.  I try to visit them whenever I'm in the SF area... If you love tea, give them a try.
author: Jane A.

description:
I am new to the whole tea universe but I decided to drop in to Aroma and see what great tea is like. The owner was extremely nice and knowledgeable. First trip was some jasmine team. It was heavenly. Second trip was more impulse, and we got some jasmine plus some oolong ginger tea. OK, that was even better. A few more trips and we have gotten all sorts of tea. Some are wild guesses and some are from tastings at the shop. All of them are MfIng Pterodactyl good. As I am writing this we are having some Honey Orchid Dan Chong. It is crazy good. Crazy good. 

In short. Go here. Buy tea. Be happy.
author: Donna B.

description:
Want some good tea with some fun atmosphere while you wait. This guy has been brewing tea for a long time here (9 plus years). A group of us came here unexpectedly and he took us in with a smile and let us sample teas while we talked. Eventually one by one we decided to all get cups of tea to go. He did a great job keeping us laughing while making all our tea. 
I would highly recommend this place to anyone who wants to expound their tea experience.
author: Steve V.

description: Never buy boxed tea again. Do yourself a favor and experience something better.
author: Arlene R.

description: Another hidden gem in Inner Richmond! If you are a legit tea lover who doesn't mind breaking the bank for quality leaves, you will love this place. There's a wall full of canisters of teas to choose from and you can sample any of them! They're really generous with their samples too. Prices range from around $25-80 for 4oz. Really pricey, but the few teas we tried were amazing. We didn't end up buying anything that day, but the guy working was super nice anyway. They also make hot or cold tea drinks to-go which I found out after I left. I'll be back for that for sure.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Try their Organic Ceremonial Grade Uji Matcha

I've been trying to find a coffee alternative for years and believe that I have stumbled on something that will allow me to make the change. For those that don't know, matcha tea is extremely high in antioxidants (whole leaf consumed) and is very easy to prepare and make. Though one traditionally will whisk the matcha powder in hot water --- nobody has time for that. Instead, I simply place about a tablespoon worth in my water bottle, shake and go close deals. The flavor profile is highly aromatic with a sweet undertone accompanied by a creamy mouthful of green tea zest. Additionally, after an arduous search on both ebay, amazon and competitive tea spots, Aroma Tea Shop's Uji Matcha's pricing is simply the best. You're going to be hard pressed to find a 2-oz bag of exclusive, organic, ceremonial grade matcha, made by an award winning grower for only $27 (you wont... I've looked). The grower was awarded by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in Japan... you bet he knows his shit.

tldr - Try matcha tea as a healthy alternative to coffee... Their matcha is supreme - taste, quality, and price wise.
author: Kai Kane A.

description:
BREWING THE BAY: Chinese and Taiwanese loose leaf teas, flavored teas (mostly fruity and floral)

Fantastic. Place.

I've been to a lot of tea shops in my life and Aroma Tea Shop shattered my highest expectations--so much so that I have a sinking feeling that even IT won't be able to recreate its own amazing first experience the next time I go there. After all, they say nothing is ever as good as your first high....

I could gush and rave about this place to the fullest extent, but then you'd be reading this review until the apocalypse. So instead, I will make use of my (useless) English degree and do my best to SUCCINCTLY convey why this place rocks so hard:

1) It is a classic mom 'n' pop, family-run establishment: Haymen Da Luz and his lovely wife Ying Wu started Aroma seven years ago, and in between growing their family (they have an adorable son and beautiful daughter), they've grown their inventory, space and client base.

2) Haymen: His hilarious, sardonic wit is outmatched only by his extensive knowledge (and obvious love) of tea. He's sarcastic and dry, but never obnoxious, snooty or condescending. Both novices and experts are made to feel welcome as he cheerfully steeps gaiwan after gaiwan of hot tea. When I was there, there was a young Caucasian woman seated next to me who was completely new to the world of tea. She worked at a tasting room in a winery, so her judgment of "taste" was skewed completely toward wine. Haymen never once made her feel left out and answered all of her questions with friendly assuredness.

3) The selection of (mostly Chinese and Taiwanese) teas: Aroma packs a lot into a small space. Floor-to-ceiling shelves house large, bright, metal canisters of Asian teas of every varietal, the name and price clearly labeled on each canister along with a bright, colorful picture of the tea leaves. There are also cakes of pu-erh, boxes of flowering teas (perfect gifts for tea-loving friends) and discounted bags of various tisanes (e.g. lavender and rose combos). Which leads me to my next point....

4) FREE, UNLIMITED TASTINGS OF YOUR CHOICE OF TEAS: Unlike the (awful) tea shops in Chinatown that offer a quick gongfu-like preparation of pre-selected, watered-down teas, Haymen encourages his customers to sample as many of the store's teas as they want, free of charge. This means that if you want to try premium oolong that sells for $80/4 oz, Haymen will happily go into the back room, lug out a giant box of tea leaves (the box is as big as a toddler) and steep as much of the expensive oolong for you to drink as you want. Not that anyone would make him do that.....*whistles*. In other, less complicated scenarios, you simply point to a canister and say you want to try that. Repeat until satisfied.

5) The rest of the inventory: Aroma offers a great selection of reasonably priced Chinese and Taiwanese-style teaware. This is the place to go to buy whole gongfu sets or a la carte parts including gaiwans, teapots, brewing trays, tea picks, tea cups and wooden coasters. There are also glass teapots and one-touch tea makers. I found most of the teaware to be of good quality with beautiful colors and designs, in addition to being affordable. You now have no excuse to buy the overpriced teaware of soulless chains like Teavana.

6) The brown frog that changes colors: Ask Haymen to show you if he doesn't automatically offer to. It's cute.

Gan Bei! :)
author: Josephine L.

description:
This place is heaven for dedicated tea drinkers. It's not cheap also, but the tea is quality and sourced directly from plantations so I didn't mind opening my wallet. 

My boyfriend and I visited after reading wonderful things on Yelp. The shop was empty when we walked in, but within minutes the shop owner had pulled about five different canisters off their wall and was preparing samples. We sampled close to ten teas, while she told us about her family's trips to China and Taiwan. I wanted to buy and sample them all.

I left with my favorite, a new tea cup, and some awesome idea for future travels. I cannot wait to visit again (when I have more money)!
author: Haylee L.

description: Great Store with thoroughly knowledgeable and friendly owners/staff to introduce you to the Asian art of Tea drinking and enjoyment. Haymen is a funny guy and will not hesitate to let you sample his fine wares. I enjoyed the tea samplings and left the shop with some great tea that I now drink daily!
author: Samuel S.

description:
They have a wonderful selection of various flavors and

THEY HAVE A GROUPON! 

https://www.groupon.com/deals/aroma-tea-shop-1-1
author: Benjamin D.

description:
Jessie Tang was on duty & her job was to assist me in finding the perfect tea.
Fortunately, this cozy tea shop seems to have it all, offering endless varietals.
This is why I need Jessie to help me.
Unfortunately, Jessie was in a less than stellar mood that day. I asked her to sample the teas for purchase. "Yes, sample free if you spend 20$. But otherwise, 5$ to sample." 
Not to worry, I told her, I'm here to buy. The tasting was free.

Jessie offered me two teas to taste. The most expensive tea they offer, which is what she steered me to, and a gorgeous black mango tea, that I chose.
When asked, I told her I wanted something with strawberry or mango, and that I prefer black tea. Why she took me straight to an unflavored tea is beyond me, but Jessie Tang, I'm on to you! 

The price of the tea was, how shall I say this delicately, expensive, for how few ounces you get. I'm sure rent is due the same time every month, but I learned my lesson, and having not really felt there was any benefit to sampling & buying tea in this amazing tea-locality in my own backyard, it's back to Amazon where I can get 2 lbs for 20 bucks.
And Jessie, this is where I leave you!
author: Johnny K.

description:
The Aroma Tea Shop is your tea tasting utopia in the Inner-Richmond. Once you enter the store, you see shelves of popcorn-sized barrels of tea and right in the middle is a custom-designed tea bar where you can try sample teas for free. The man helping us (I believe the owner) gave us so many teas to try and tidbits of facts about each one we were trying- even allowing us to smell the tea leaves before boiling them.
You can buy tea leaves by the ounces and this place has a wide array of different tea leaves to purchase. My go-to tea is Genmaicha, which you can order 4oz for $12.50- probably around 80 cups! If you want to go on the expensive side, they have different oolang teas and ginseng teas which can range up to $80 for 4oz. 
I feel like The Aroma Tea Shop has an endless supply and selection of teas and if you're looking to find out what your favorite tea is, this is the place to go to find out. You can also purchase serving pots and cups here. Big fan and will be coming back!
author: Grace L.

description:
literally the best tea place ever!!!
go there the tea is absolutely the best!!
also there tea isnt fake,its real tea that they picked out in china!!
author: Fontine D.

description:
Giving four stars for the benefit of the doubt. It was definitely a 3-star experience.

I'm told the owner was not here that day. The woman who was there did not have a wealth of information on teas. She did not invite us to sample teas unless we specifically asked. She convinced me not to buy the Thai tea blend: "It's like a hot dog. Everything is in there."

Teas felt like they cost way too much, but again, benefit of the doubt: this is San Francisco. I'm sure it costs enough for the store space and to import the stuff.

It should be obvious that you shouldn't come in here and sample product you don't intend to buy. I feel that's true at a lot of shop that offer this experience, but worth noting just the same.
author: David S.

description: I was oddly intimidated by the setup here. I like tea, but I don't really know a lot about it. Because of this, I waited until a friend who was familiar with Aroma Tea Shop took me here. This was completely ridiculous on my part. The shop is super open, accessible, and easy to deal with, regardless of your level of tea expertise. Additionally, I didn't feel pressured into buying more expensive tea, and didn't feel frowned upon for getting some more inexpensive choices, too. At first I was reluctant to sample, but the proprietor was very friendly and encouraged lots of tastings. I look forward to coming back.
author: Lisa K.

description: Absolutely fantastic!  The best loose leaf tea experience ever!  The owner Haymen was super fun, incredibly knowledgeable and more than willing to sample almost any tea we asked about.  Had an enormous selection and knew everything about each of them.  Very impressed and highly recommend!
author: Vivienne V.

description: Hayman is extensively knowledgeable in all things tea.  From where it grows, to what it heals, to what the taste reminds you of.  Been coming for years, don't see myself stopping anytime soon.
author: Natasha B.

description: This guy has the greatest mixes and sense of humor. Awesome teas with the best nomenclature.  I love the fresh new experimental vibe in the tea. Addicted to blue people and black general, I tried staple high end teas from other traditional shops, but always come back here because I miss the fun factor that these teas have. Life feels great with good tea!  Make sure to try the sweet and creamy ...
author: Van X.

description:
Man, I LOVE Aroma tea shop.  I didn't know there was such a thing as tea until I stopped drinking coffee a year ago.  Well, I knew there was tea, but I thought it began and ended with the 100 box of generic green tea, Lipton-style.  That was enough of a caffeine delivery system for me.

But come the loss of my beloved coffee--one day, all must either be consumed or part with their drug of choice, like some dysfunctional relationship--I suddenly realized that otherwise functional Lipton was tasting like grass-infused sawdust.

So I remembered going into the place and getting tea samples from Heymen, the punk rock tea master, at the amazing marble tea bar and thinking, hey, I should check that out again.  I went in and got about 10 small samples, and trying them at my office, identifying which I liked best and especially which infused caffeine most effectively.

Going there now, to refill my stock of smokey and powerful green teas (what I've learned is my preference), always is a highlight of my week.  Heymen is such a knowledgeable and unassuming character (last time he points to the T-shirt on the way that says, simply, "Tea Master," and says, "Yeah, that's all you need."), yet with a wicked punky edge, who is so thoroughly and effortless a master of his trade, that I can ask any stupid question, or broad request, and he's able to interpret and respond immediately.  Really, if it were just a tea shop with a stodgy old character who made me feel as ignorant as I am, I would never have come back.

Aroma is really a little jewel that I hope every tea drinker gets to experience.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Fresh scents.

More tea variations than ever thought possible. High end accessories for pouring that perfect cup. Friendly staff serving single cups for $3.

Bit under the weather and in desperate need to kick this bug, the South African Rooibos Chai with lemongrass, ginger, cinnamon and vanilla seemed as good a bet as any.

Felt a bit better the next day. Felt really good about patronizing Aroma.
author: Jason B.

description:
Great place for any level of tea lover. I consider myself a newbie with tea, so it was great getting to smell and taste everything before I spent my money.

In the past I've bought online after doing extensive research, and this tea is of similar quality as some of the better tea sites (and you don't have a shipping fee if you go in person!).

Hayman knows a lot and I felt  like I got a lot of information without even asking many questions. It was very educational :)

I highly recommend going in person, even though he DOES ship.
author: Ellie M.

description:
I like to go on quests for food. When I was a boy in the Midwest in the 90's, it took about 6 months to locate a passion fruit. When I was living in Europe in the 2000's, I fell in love with a Polish cheese called oscypek that took me about four years to locate in the United States (gotta go to Chicago). I also fell under the spell of a Chinese tea called Golden Spiral that I would get a teahouse in Prague.

I searched and searched for years upon my return to America for this tea, but could not find it. One day, I poked my head into Heyman's shop and wa-la! Golden Spiral was sitting right there on his shelf. Now I have a source for my fix, and I've had the opportunity to sample countless other delicious teas. I really enjoy coming by, trying teas, and hanging with Heyman, who's a funny, welcoming guy. 

Do yourself a favor and stop by for some tea.
author: Jason K.

description:
Comprehensive selection of Teas from the mainland and Taiwan. Haymen will fill you in on what is necessary vis a vis tea preparation and enjoyment. Tea here is noticeably fresher and 'perkier' than similar shops that I have frequented. 


Better still Haymen will pour you a cup (or several) i have not been to another shop where the proprieter is as genial as Haymen. He definitely cares about making loyal customers. 

There is also a full line up of tea accessories (cups, kettles, serving sets) Decently priced. 

Great store, great experience. If I lived closer I would be there often.
author: Ethan K.

description: Came right near closing - but the person there was happy to do a tea tasting (5$ per person) for us anyway. We found out a little bit about each tea, for example that the chinese lapsang souchong is more roasty than smokey! They also had lovely tea tables and gaiwans. There was a little bit of (common) false information around (that caffeine decreases drastically after first steep) but overall knowledgeable and tasty!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Amazing hidden gem.
Hayden is a great host, and you can pick between many, many different varieties of tea! You will have a great time at Aroma!
author: Nicola C.

description:
Didn't know about this store until I was walking along Clement and saw it to the side. I was in need of some loose tea and wanted to see if they carried anything that I like. I usually go to Vital Tea Leaf in Chinatown, but I knew I wasn't going there anytime soon. Pretty small location with a small bar with free tea tasting. I tried a variety of their ginseng teas but didn't like what they offered. I told them that I usually got Blue People Tea from Vital Tea Leaf and lo-and-behold, they carry it too! Left with a bag of it and went on my merry way.

It is located around Clement, so parking is fairly difficult but if I'm in the area and in need of tea, I'll be stopping by.
author: Kitty K.

description: Just did a tea tasting there with one of my classes, and I'm so glad I chose to go here instead of the wine-tasting event we could have gone to. Learned SO much about tea in just an hour; Haymen (the owner) is super funny and extremely knowledgeable about tea without being pretentious at all. I never considered tea-management as a career but this visit definitely got me interested in learning more. The teas are pretty pricey but I've never tasted anything like the ones I sampled there before, seriously amazing! The Blue People tea was my favorite. I ended up buying a Gaiwan tea set and will be back soon to buy some tea!
author: Serena C.

description:
When I go out - I don't get wasted. I get hydrated.

I'm not a big drinker. At all. Whenever I meet up with friends at bars,  I like to match their shots and overly sweet cocktails with glasses of water. By the end of the night - I'm feeling alert, revived, and energetic - and they're sluggish, tired, and ready to go home.

Recently, with the wave of colds and flu that been going around this city, I've become even more focused on staying hydrated and keeping my body healthy with antioxidants.

One of my favorite ways to accomplish this - is by drinking tea.

Aroma Tea Shop is an ideal tea oasis for learning about all of the health benefits of tea,  a great spot to buy high quality tea, and even a unique spot to be moderately social as well, while being schooled in the wonder that is tea.

Aroma Tea Shop has a small darling tea bar area where you can sample teas for free, while you decide on a tea - that suits you. Throughout the sampling process - Haymen will educate you about each tea and all of the intricacies about that particular tea. 

We asked him for a recommendation and he spoke highly of the Blue People Oolong. He was right. It's wonderful. It coats your throat with a slightly sweet after-taste and after just a couple of small cups - I instantly felt a surge of energy. My skin even felt smoother and more moisturized.

If you're looking for a distinct tea adventure in which you can learn first-hand about wondrous teas, without pretension, and with a couple of spoonfuls of wit -  then come to Aroma Tea Shop. 

You will not be disappointed.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Amazing experience!!!!
A must if you are in china town
Extremely kind and helpful.  Tea tasting trumps wine tasting by far.
author: A S.

description:
I need tea.  And I want to have fun buying it!  Do you?  Let's go! 

There are several tea shops in the city but rare are the ones who will take the time to not only allow you to smell and view the leaves, but also let you taste any one that you are interested in and be extremely knowledgeably about every single variety sold.  

Do you want to know what area of the world this tea is from?  How it compares to a hundred other teas?  When it was cultivated and what the actual tea farm looks like?  Haymen, the owner, knows all.   It means a lot to me that I am buying product from someone who has been to the source.  To be clear, this tea room specializes in mostly Asian teas.   When faced with a huge selection with crazy names like Dong Ding, Blue People, and Iron Goddess, Haymen is like a tour guide to exploring all of these wonderful varieties.  I grew up drinking several Chinese and Japanese teas but this place introduced me to dozens I have never heard  of.  For instance, it is amazing to taste each one and realize how drastically different one tea is from another even if they are both green.  

When you walk into the shop, you'll notice a marble bar with small stools.  That's the tasting station.  The best part about shopping here is pulling yourself up to a stool and letting Haymen introduce you to new and interesting teas like Longevity Eyebrow.  You can watch him brew the tea, have you smell the leaves both dry and wet, and then taste a small amount.  Have I mentioned that Haymen is hilarious?  He has a great sense of humor and sets a very relaxed atmosphere where you can feel free to socialize with the other tasters and  share opinions. 

Since the tea is loose leaf, you can choose to purchase by weight or by price.  For instance, I can choose to buy 2 oz. of a tea or just ask that they give me $20 worth.  

My favorite tea is the Supreme Taiwan Jin Xuan Milk Oolong.  This tea is so good that I am crazy addicted to it now.   Brewed between 30-60 seconds,  it has a soft green floral taste with this buttery flavor to it that is completely unexpected and yet natural to this particular tea.  Please stop by the shop and ask to taste it. I guarantee you will never have had anything like it before and once you try it, you'll be blown away by it's uniqueness.  I'm usually not one to lay down a lot of money for tea but I gladly do for this one.   You can check out this tea here on their online store: 
http://www.aromateashop.com/store/index.php?act=viewProd&productId=85
author: Courtney Y.

description:
A plethora of tea options, served with a sense of humor!

Like everyone else on Yelp says, you can get as many samples as you want (well...I did see a sign in the store that said four to six, but am guessing that if you're actually interested in buying, you may be able to sneak a seventh in).

Of course, everyone has their own tastes, but if you're a new tea drinker and want some recommendations to try, I suggest Genmai Cha (green tea / toasted rice), jasmine pearls, rose petals, and / or one of the Oolongs (I personally like the ones that taste roasted).

In addition to Haymen's jokes, there are also several one liners posted on the wall that are really amusing too:

"What make you think I am Chinese? I am KOREAN. Do I look Chinese?"
-Dave Chappelle
author: Jessica C.

description:
Definitely a great place to go for tea! My best friend recommended this place to me and referred to Haymin as her "Tea Guy". I couldn't agree more. He is definitely the person I would come to for anything regarding tea.

Haymin definitely knows his tea. We asked questions about what teas were good for each sickness and he knew everything off the top of his head. He even had a placard that we could refer to. 

Something that was awesome was that he definitely let us sample almost every tea we bought.

He's really funny too. Go here for some awesome tea.

Try Blue People Oolong, and Rose Tea!
author: Odes K.

description:
I had a really pleasant experience at Aroma this weekend. Dropped in and sat down for a tasting, the woman serving was very kind and patiently took us through probably a dozen different teas. You can try anything in the store and prices go from around $11 for 4oz to around $45 for very fancy stuff. The teas I purchased were around $22 each.

While some reviewers mention feeling pressure to buy tea, I didn't feel any whatsoever. I think it's natural that you'll feel an obligation (self-imposed) to buy if you've been tasting tea for an hour, but I never felt like I was in a sales pitch. In the end I found 3 teas I really like and have been brewing like crazy all weekend... have.. to... peeeeeeeeee! 

I suspect they're reading their Yelp reviews carefully... one reviewer expressed concerns over how they charge sales tax and I noticed they have a detailed explanation over their cash register about sales tax... coincidence?!?!

Anywhoooo, what a great way to spend half an hour in the Richmond...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
the guy who owns this shop, haymen, makes a lot of puns - good puns, they really work! - he is fun to talk with. further, he + his wife go around the world on tea buying trips; they have amazing teas and he knows about all of them. 

i buy tea to make iced tea. i like flower teas, not fruit, which narrows my choices. haymen has led me to great green, rose, lavender and jasmine teas. not to mention genmai cha!

i will always come here for tea, even after my upcoming move to the north bay.
author: diana m.

description:
Yup, free tea tasting! 

I walked in finding a group of 5 locals laughing having a tea "party" with the owner (Haymen I gather). As I was tasting I noticed that this joint seems to have some sort of a cult following and locals walk in and out,  chit chatting with Haymen, not walking out before purchasing something.

Anyway, I got to business and let Haymen know I what I was in the market for.  I wanted mint black tea but he only had peppermint black tea. I was still impressed as most places don't even have that. I tasted around 5 teas. The lychee black tea was exceptionally good and the coconut black tea was exotic with a silkiness to it. 

The "human oolong" tea wasn't anything special. They were out of Matcha tea (apparently it's out of season?)

I just had my pepermint black tea this morning and I'm STILL wide awake 14 hours later! Quality stuff :)
author: Kathy S.

description:
I was first introduced to this place by my sister who had a deal for 30-50% off the total purchase. Even though this place is small and only has two locations (Clement Street in the Inner Richmond and Washington Street in Chinatown), I am really glad the manager/Tea Master is willing to get exposure for the shop through online/mobile deals! 

Tea Master, Haymen, has always made me feel welcomed from the minute I set foot in the shop. Walking in, you'll immediately notice no free space along the walls because the walls are stocked to the brim with different kinds of teas--organized based on the leaves and flavors. The shop also carries teapots, strainers, cute tea sets, thermos bottles, and more to complement your tea leaves purchase. Haymen always welcomes visitors to come sit with him and sample teas. He is extremely generous with his portions and endlessly lets you taste-test specialty teas to your delight (and if you're lucky enough to come when he is pouring tea for other customers, he'll always pour you a cup of what they're having too)! It's like he creates a tea party for all customers to pause their day to sit, take a breather, and relax with some tea. Haymen has a vast amount of knowledge of tea leaves, tea flavors, the leaves' origins and age, and how to attain the best flavor from each particular tea. He also demonstrates the proper way to coat your tea pots and steep your tea leaves right in front of you. It's pretty entertaining to watch him do his demonstrations, especially because at the end of it, you know he'll be serving you whatever he is working on!

I have an inclination to lean towards green and white teas. I originally started with Oolong tea (the shop has a HUGE variety of Oolong teas and unfortunately I don't remember the exact name of the one I bought!) but I have definitely grown to love the White Fur Silver Needle tea. As the name suggests, it is a white tea. In addition to considering the variety of tea flavors (such as one particular white or green tea or another), you also should consider the age of the leaves you purchase. I originally started with an aged Silver Needle tea, but after I tried young leaves of Silver Needle tea, I have never gone back! The younger leaves are such a beautiful, vibrate green color and the aroma is slightly fruity (whereas the Oolong teas would smell more woodsy). Young White Fur Silver Needle tea leaves produce a lighter shade of brown compared to green and black teas when hot (NEVER boiling) water is added and it leaves a more subtle aftertaste in your mouth compared to green and black teas. 

Since I don't drink coffee at all, tea has become my alternative caffeine booster in the mornings at work. Haymen packs 1-oz. or 2-oz. bag(s) of leaves in a Zip-loc bag and sticks a label with the name of the tea on it. The label also gives instructions on how to make the most of this particular tea. I can't give specific prices of the various teas because they vary based on the age of the leaves, the type of tea, etc. But I know a 2-oz. bag of young White Fur Silver Needle tea leaves costs roughly $30. I have been here three times now and not once has Haymen charged me at full price. The last time I came here, I bought two 2-oz. bags of tea (one was the young White Fur Silver Needle and the other was another white tea, Dragon's Mill or something like that) and Haymen only charged me $16 for both! This is already after I had sampled at least 3 cups of teas prior to my purchase!

The price may bother some, but the way I see it is you come to Aroma Tea Shop knowing you want tea that you cannot find in a regular supermarket. The other reason would be you yourself cannot properly distinguish teas and would like an expert to help you pinpoint the exact flavors that satisfy your palette. While parking may be difficult to find around Clement Street (meters only for the most part), it shouldn't deter you from giving this place a try at least once (if not to purchase anything, at least to stop and get a drink after dehydrating, long shopping sprees around Clement Street). Overall, the customer service is UNBEATABLE and I have never left this tea shop unhappy!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Great shop - high quality products and wonderful customer service

I brew my own hot and iced tea at work to avoid the free Lipton and and fend off my soda habit. This shop has a great selection of teas. The owner is very knowledgeable and helpful. There's a little serving area in the middle where you can sample the teas, and they are very good. The owner is an entertaining mix of sardonic and passionate about his work. I buy the lychee iced tea blend here and make it at work. It's a little sweet and has some distinctive floral notes. Their "Blue People" tea is a very nice oolong. I also tried their peach white tea, and it's very good.

I tend to like my teas a bit sweeter than some, and this place has some great slightly sweet tasting teas. There's also a great selection of traditional black and green teas here.
author: Carter S.

description: This shop is right near my place and, as a tea lover, I'm ashamed it took me long to visit. Haymen is very courteous and helpful. His passion and knowledge about tea are very obvious. He figured out which teas I would like best with just a couple questions. No more blindly buying tea off the internet for me!
author: Brittany L.
