author: Thomas M.

description:
My coworkers and I walked into this place to pass time since we still had 17 minutes left on the parking meter. None of us had the experience of an actual sit down tea tasting, so we were asking a lot of questions about the tea, steeping and such. Haymen, the owner, was our "bartender" and was very entertaining, friendly and helpful, which made our experience really fun.
 I didn't know that rinsing tea before you steep it (which isn't long at all) opens up the aroma. I chose our first tea, which was Candy Apple Black Tea, which sounded good after our full lunch. He rinsed it, then steeped it, and then poured it into these tea shot glasses. I loved the whole atmosphere a lot, we were the only ones in there, so was a relaxing, fun time we had learning  about the different teas Haymen seemed to know a various amount about. 

If we didn't have to go back to work, I swear I'd be in the rest of the afternoon trying all these teas, seeing how they would affect me. Good thing there's no such thing as Teaholics Anonymous!
author: Sharon B.

description:
review isn't about dissatisfaction with the service which was acceptable.
review rates the tea: "phoenix ear" ($72/lb).

looks like over 100 "jars" of tea in the shop.

pour: $3 cup
-very weak flavors till end of cup, then there was  burst of flavor.
-mostly slightly aromatic.

tea drips:
-can order online also. some discounts.
author: Victor G.

description:
I love this place; it's my favorite tea shop. This is significant because:

1. my parents travel to China to buy tea. It is one of their reasons for flying their butts out there.
2. everyone in my family has a cupboard dedicated to tea and teaware
3. buying tea from other stores gives you teabags with crappy tea, or whole tea that is crazy expensive and limited, or a BS experience of 'americanized' tea talk.
4. their tea is fantastic and great value for how much tea you get. huge tins everywhere.

I love the guy that runs this shop. Free tea-tastings are such a great idea to find what you like from the 30~ varieties of oolong and pu-erh. There are some crazy tastes like milk oolong, phoenix oolong or orchid oolong, etc. 

If you want to get educated on tea, check this place out. Everyone needs some old pu-erh, a tie guan yin, and several oolongs. Great value for the tea, and nice samples all around.
author: Jade L.

description:
Yes, Im a fan! Wow what wonderful selection of teas. They had a great staff that works there and have always been ver help and knowledgable about teas. 
Thank you again and see you soon!
author: Mya A.

description:
This is my first yelp review. I made an account just for this place. I went in to buy an obscure tea that I wanted which seemed hard to find elsewhere. I was not expecting to have such a good time or stay for over an hour talking to the owner. This is the most fun I've had shopping for tea in at least 5 years and I've been a pretty intense tea drinker for about 7. 

How it works is you go in and the owner, Haymen, asks you what sort of tea you are looking for. Then he'll bring out a few different types for you, tell you about them, and make samples for you. 

This and another shop in Chinatown are run jointly by Haymen and his wife, and they do it all. The frequently go to China and Taiwan to buy teas directly themselves from buying the tea from farmers to running their shops in SF. The fact that they go straight to the farmers and choose what teas are worth buying means you are getting some of the best tea you possibly could without physically going to China yourself.

What makes the experience even better is the passion that Haymen brings to his work. Like I said, I came in not even looking to buy any normal tea. To be honest, I've become really frustrated with tea over the past few years because I felt like it is impossible to get good tea in the states. He started by making me some Longjing and it made me remember how it is supposed to taste and why I liked it so much to begin with. From there we just talked for a while and I sampled quite a few different teas and can say that across the board the quality of tea he sells is superb. I left with a few different types of teas and I've been drinking (and enjoying!) more tea in the past week than I have in the past few years. 

A must visit for tea lovers!
author: Cadmium C.

description:
Yelp brought me and my girlfriend here one day when she wanted to buy some teas (as a substitute for all the coffee, unnatural juices, soda, and alcohol). We were greeted by a young gentleman (the Tea Master) and he offered us to have a seat at the counter. There was already a couple sitting down before us and they were sampling/buying the various teas that he was suggesting. 

It was pretty cool and felt like I was at a bar; he'd pour us tea shots and we all got drunk off tea. We asked for recommendations and to try various other teas and so he did. (There's probably 100+ different teas here to choose from). There was a ton of refreshing teas that we drank and when we found a tea that we liked, we purchased it (sold by lbs). We spent a good 30-40 minutes just sitting down chilling and discussing about teas and the healthy properties of each of them. 

Only thing is that the lbs of tea adds up and is pricey. The couple that was there before us spent well over $150+. We left spending $60.
author: Albert L.

description:
Based on yelp reviews, I went here today to stock up on green tea and scope out teaware. They have a better selection of loose leaf than some other tea shops, with more reasonable prices. They also have a separate "connoisseur section" which I was embarrassed, but driven to purchase from.  

I was hoping to try some particular types but didn't want to interrupt the tea man for a tasting while he was helping a restaurant owner buy bulk, sampling a number teas with his lady. Instead I just made my purchases and will return for that.  

I bought a mid-grade pu-erh, a high grade organic Japanese green, and some blooming tea flowers for about $70. Not bad. I will be making it one of my regular hunting and gathering spots.

Recommended.
author: Adrienne K.

description: The owner is fantastic and really super helpful, we have been buying pu'er tea here for years now. The other day we went in there to purchase some green tea and were rushed along by another sales person, we have never encountered before. We ended up purchasing some jasmine tea which we were quite dissatisfied with --not because it is not good quality tea, but rather I guess we don't like jasmine (sorry Beijing). I wish the sales person would have stopped and let us try the tea, because then we would have known. Alas.
author: Jenn D.

description: Great customer service. The owner has a dry wit and keeps it entertaining. This is a family owned business with a great product. I highly recommend it for an easy going place to go on a date if you'd like to skip the coffee shop.
author: Joel C.

description: What a find! I've walked past the Aroma Tea Shop, but never went in until today. They haved an enormous selection of loose tea leaves, a very knowledgeable and helpful young man behind the counter, and fair prices.  After giving up on finding loose tea leaves (not bags, please!), for the lapsong souchong I was looking for, I was tickled to find exactly what I wanted here. It will become a regular stopping place for me.
author: suzanne s.

description:
The Tea Master is in da house!!!

No sorry its not me, its my good buddy HAYMEN!

Now you might be thinking that this is another biased review, The reason Haymen and I are friends is because i came into check out his tea shop and has some tea with him.

I am not a big coffee drinker, I do enjoy it every once in a while but I love TEA! Green tea, Black tea, Oolong, Ceylon, English, White tea, Chai, I love them all. Tea bags are good for convience but horrible for fully experiencing a tea. I used to only drink tea in tea bags but after switching to loose leaf theres no going back for me. A cup of Green tea everyday is very healthy for you so i recommend it.  I found ATS on yelp and decided to go and check it out . As i entered i was intimidated , there were so many different types of tea on the wall. I didn't know where to start!

Haymen offers free tea tastingsand based on one's you try or are familar with Haymen can make suggestions and let you try even more teas. It was on a Wednesday that i walked in, mid afternoon and it wasn't a very busy day. I ended up staying there for about 2hrs talking with Haymen and trying a lot of different types teas. We found some common history between us which is how we became friends. I am a regular customer at ATS and can't stop coming back when i need to feed my tea craving. 

Another reason that really keeps me coming back is the wealth of knowledge about tea that Haymen has is amazing. Everytime i go in i learn something new and learn tips on how to get the best out of my tea. Haymen even goes to China to visit the farms. What more dedication can you have? Haymen is a tea master for sure! So if you are in need of some good loose leaf tea come by and pay Haymen a visit. You will definitely enjoy your Tea experience here!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
The dude is cool, helpful and has a great sense of humor. You can tell by his signs up around the shop (quotes from Dave Chappelle to Mao), and he asks if he can help once you come in. He doesn't pressure like other tea gurus I've been to and even gave me a little freebie sample based on the teas I bought. 

I spent a nice rainy day in Green Apple and then here. His shop is a great way to round out the 6th/Clement corner.
author: Kelly C.

description: Had an awesome experience here, tasting a bunch of teas and walking out with some fine finds. The owner was there and he was awesome, Gave me the royal treatment even though I was using a groupon. Highly recommend!
author: Karen M.

description:
Aroma Tea Shop is one of my favorite places in San Francisco.  I don't think of this place as much a tea store than live, interactive theater; Hayman being the star, of course.  He has a dry, dead-pan humor that comes across easy and genuine, and you can learn a lot about tea while having a great time tasting his wares.

Some of the tea is very pricey and it's easy to end up spending way more than you were anticipating.  That being said, most of the best tasting tea I've had is from Aroma Tea Shop.
author: Janice J.

description: so wonderful!! seriously some of the best customer service i've ever had. super cool guy owns the place. so many tasty teas to choose from and had the opportunity to try a few. i'll never go anywhere else for tea again!
author: Caitlin D.

description:
While waiting to be seated at Burma Superstar we took stroll around the neighborhood and we found this really nice cozy small little tea shop....

We browsed through the funny titles on different tea jars... For ex: one was called Vanilla tea with a pic of Vanilla ice on it! hahaha...there were other funny ones too...

The owner/manager of the tea shop was catering to a couple of customers who seemed to be doing some tea tasting :)

We bought a couple of those flower teas that bloom when soaked in water.

Will definitely go back when I am there next to try more teas
author: Kinjal S.

description:
Really awesome place to sample tea!  The owner is humorous and friendly, and let's you sample whichever tea you want from his huge selection.

Definitely try the muscat oolong and the blue people tea!
author: Jay G.

description: Awesome tea tasting. Blue people made my day. Fun, interesting activity and healthy too!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Oh man. This tea shop was the best thing that I could have possibly stumbled upon today!

Let's get this straight: I love tea. Black tea, green tea, oolong tea, rooibos, herbal, froofroo-flavored -- I love it. It's what keeps me going every day.

That being said, the tea tasting experience at Aroma Tea was totally new for me. It was like wandering into a winery and being poured a bunch of wines in a row without having to ask for it or pay a tasting fee. I thought I had died and gone to heaven, which happened to be run by a tea guru/comedian!

I think they literally have everything at this shop -- including pu erh, which was also something I had never tried. I'll admit that I was fascinated by the tea "bar," and the constant flow of hot water and tea leaves. I have no idea how long we were there, but we must have tried about 10 teas, and left with 4. 

Good tea is not cheap, but it is worth every penny. I would recommend this place to all of my friends, tea enthusiasts and tea novices alike.
author: Liz E.

description:
I've always been a Stash ginger-lemon tea drinking girl but when a girlfriend and I happened on this tea shop in my 'hood, my mind changed.  Free tea tastings.  And don't let the word "free" fool you.  It's a performance too.  The owner is an entertainer and seriously knows his stuff.

My hubs bought me a gift cert here for Christmas and I loved spending every penny.  I look forward to opening my bags of tea every night and sipping stuff that not only tastes great but has great health benefits.  

Very much a Clement Street hidden gem!
author: Christina K.

description: Best tea shop in the Bay area:).  Parking lot not really a lot but off street space for customers down street, very nice perk - just to the South of the shop a couple houses!
author: Traci L.

description: My boyfriend and I spent a lovely afternoon learning about tea.  Haymen was friendly and knowledgeable, with an excellent sense of humor.  We bought some fantastic tea that we have been enjoying for quite some time now; loose leaf tea can be reused and a little goes a long way, which is great for my student budget.  My boyfriend wants to go back with some friends soon, because it is such a great group activity; he likened it to wine tasting, but without a hangover or any impact on one's ability to drive.  Plus I am convinced that the blue people oolong I purchased helped me get over the flu.  All kinds of awesome.
author: Lauren A.

description: I was blown away by Aroma tea shop! We drove to SF to check this place out because we had a LivingSocial deal.  So glad because I would've never found this hidden gem without that.  I walk in and see this young asian guy all tatted up with his boxers partially showing.  I thought he was just some random guy they hired to work here, but he was the owner named Haymen (sp?) and he was incredibly knowledgable about all the teas.  He could tell you their origins and the flavors.  He may have even been to where the tea leaves were harvested (as evidenced by all the pictures) and knows how the leaves have been processed and how that plays into the flavors.  Crazy I know!  He was super friendly and invited us to sit down with him and try a bunch of different teas.  He is seriously an expert.  I would definitely come back to support him and this business and get my loose leaf tea here.
author: Chantal T.

description:
Ever been intimidated by the tea shops in Chinatown that cater mainly to tourists and are pushy about selling you the expensive stuff without much time to spare on explaining or demoing the goods?  Enter 'Aroma Tea Shop', totally unexpected tea awesomeness. Tucked away in the Inner Richmond, this store offers all the teas you can find in C-Town in a more relaxed, cozy atmosphere. 

the guy running the shop, Haymen, is the man. Period. Go pay him a visit, you'll be glad you did.  

And PS: awesome Chinese teas make a great souvenir or gift from San Francisco, believe it or not.
author: Tomas V.

description: I love the new tea drink craze. This is one of the best place in the Bay Area to have super cool tea drinks. I love the green tea with milk here.
author: Tyler Y.

description:
I came back here last night and had an even better experience than before.  I was in with two friends for about three hours with one wonderful pot of Supreme Dong Ding Oolong and the owner must have given us around 15 tastes of other teas including a vodka white tea cocktail.  He was very generous and we tried to return the favor with purchases of different loose leaf teas, though even then he'd throw in extra tea samples.  He was very friendly and knowledgeable and all the oolongs we tried were great.  He has a reasonable selection of bill paying teas, including chai lattes and fruitier concoctions, but his selection of high quality connoisseur tea is great and very reasonably priced.  His most pricey tea ($100 for 4oz) sells for $300 at price-gouging Samovar, where you can get a $50 POT of green tea.

It's a tough area for parking, but if you stay a while, it's totally worth it.
author: Tom W.

description:
TL;DR version: OK for a free tasting, but be very cautious of buying any of the tea here.

To preface this review, I've been drinking "fine" Chinese and Japanese teas for nearly three years now, and am experienced in many aspects of tea culture and appreciation. This being said, Aroma Tea Shop has developed a reputation among other tea shops in the area that is quite different from its current ratings on Yelp. Aroma Tea is fine as an introduction to the Chinese gongfu way of brewing loose-leaf tea, but I would be extremely wary of buying tea for several reasons:

1.) Haymen, the owner, is very fast-paced and has his own very dry sense of humor as noted by many reviews which put me at a bit of unease. You may feel like you're being sold a used car at times.

2.) Price and quality are very disparate in many of the teas sold in the shop. As stated by other reviewers, the prices for many flavored teas are highly elevated for the quality (i.e. sprayed with artificial flavorings). Many of the traditional teas also are lacking in quality, yet are at a similar price to many reputable online and brick-and-mortar shops known for consistent quality.

3.) And this is really my major complaint: HONESTY. I tasted several teas in the shop, all from Taiwan, and ended up purchasing 2 oz of Jin Xuan to brew at home. This was done literally behind our backs by Haymen's wife, so we trusted that we would receive the correct one. Immediately after reaching my house, I weighed the contents of the bag on a food scale at home (my habit in dealing with new tea purveyors) and found the weight of the bag was included in the two ounces I purchased (not tared correctly). 

After brewing several separate times under different conditions, I came to the conclusion that the tea that I purchased must have been different from that which I tasted in the store, as it had a very artificial strawberry flavor not present before. I took the tea back to the shop and told Haymen my concern, but he insisted the tea was 100% naturally flavored, citing a quick google search he did in the store, afterwards dragging out the box from which he scooped my tea and showed me the "Made in Taiwan" print on the outside box to prove its authenticity.

I wasn't fully convinced, and took the tea to a local tea shop to have them assess the quality of the teas side-by-side and the difference was like night and day. Not only was there an intense artificial flavor, but it was apparently there was a storage problem with the tea at some point, as the wet leaves smelled strongly of brewers yeast. Trustworthiness is really key in buying tea, since you have to rely on the vendor giving you accurate information on what you are actually drinking. In my opinion any vendor who sells artificially flavored teas under the guise of fine tea has lost my patronage as well as my respect. 

If you're looking for an introduction to Chinese teas, I would suggest other shops in the Bay Area such as Red Blossom, Taste, or Teance where the owners are not only extremely friendly, but are honestly interested in educating people and sourcing really high quality teas. Please learn from my review, and don't make the mistake I did!

Full Disclosure: I do not work in the tea or beverage industry, but have patronized all three shops mentioned above.
author: James P.

description: OK, with all the clones appearing these days, I am gonna pipe up and say THIS is the original, my friend. Enter the imitations at your own risk.
author: Jaina D.

description: The best tea I have ever had! The owner knows tea. He has travelled and tasted all over China. The selection of Tea Kuan Yin is the best I have seen and tasted. I bought Pu Erh, Jasmine, Tea Kuan Yin and Black Currant. Way better than the Chinatown shops and well worth the trip to Richmond.
author: Jeremy R.

description: The owner is awesome!  Such a fun tea shop.  Doesn't come with the snooty hippy vibes so many tea shops emit.  Great selection, good prices.  Party time!
author: Audrey K.

description:
The owner as well as his wife (she is usually in the Richmond store) are very knowledgeable about tea, and would be able to find your favorite kind. Especially, I was impressed with the wife's professional  attitude. (sorry, i don't know her name) If you are a sales person, you should go there and learn how to sell things from her;)

I would not buy Japanese tea from this place (I am too picky when it comes to Japanese tea), but  this place can offer great selections of Chinese tea. 


Mata ikimasune!
author: Gongke Z.

description:
Their tea is very overpriced.  My friend from Turkey laughed at me when I told him how much I paid for my small packets of tea.  The tea is primo, but way too expensive for how much you get.  The lady who gave us tea spoke no English, which is not her fault, but it's more fun to be able to talk with your host.

I recommend "The Vital Leaf" in China Town instead.  This place is affordable, fun, and they have a huge selection of absolutely top notch tea.  And trust me, I drink a lot of tea.
author: Jackson W.

description: Look no further than this shop whether you are already a tea enthusiast or a total novice.  Haymen will get you set-up.  Happening by this shop during a Clement jaunt turned out to be the high-point of an already terrific day.  The only other place like it I've been in is Teance in Berkeley, but Haymen's shop is so much more welcoming and casual....I had no compunction about asking anything thanks to Haymen's warmth, humor, hospitality, and amazing knowledge of teas.  He'll get you set up with a tea that will make you very happy.  You may pay what seems like a lot, but a few ounces of tea leaves yield scores of brewed cups.  Haymen will show you.  Please go see him.  You will enjoy.  Can't wait till I can get back again.  Thanks, Haymen!
author: tim m.

description:
Haman, Shirley (the owners) and I have spent literally hundreds of hours together since they opened. They have tutored me about every nuance of Chinese teas i could ever possibly hope to learn and in return  i've
 (Haute Plate) created all sorts of magical tea-infused dishes for them, from a smokey iron goddess tea rubbed, brined and smoked pork loin to their daughter's namesake berry tea infused cupcakes with the same tea infused true buttercream frosting.

My favorite all time teas are pu er in brick form, the silver oolong balls i can't remember the name of and the really special teas they keep in tins on the tippy top shelf that Hayman treats me to from time to time. 

Tea Tastings with either of them are such a delight, they are both so incredibly knowledgeable and share that knowledge freely and with great shares of humor, laughter and showmanship, which make every trip into the shop a delightful learning and taste treat experience.

Next time you're in and finishing a tasting, ask for the grand finale.  it's a shot of a very bitter tea followed by a delightfully aromatic, smooth, long finishing tea.  Quite a bit like taking a shot of brandy after a meal to quiet a too full tummy.  And quite an experience.

Although all of their shops are delightful I still hold their flagship store on 6th Ave dearest to my heart and when I hold private tea tasting parties-which if you haven't thought of doing, please do! Haman, Shirley and I are delighted to put an unforgettable evening together for you- this is the place I bring my guests.
author: Rochelle F.

description: Love. This is where I bring people who are just getting started on tea, because Haymen will explain the options and let them taste their way to a favorite. He's fantastic about remembering people and what they like (he remembers that I like roasted oolongs), and then using that to suggest alternatives. I can spend a long time here. Generous samples, super explanations. Yes, it's hard for me to not come away with more tea than I was planning, but for such good teas, I don't really complain.
author: Scott B.

description:
We wandered in here randomly one rainy San Francisco afternoon and were greeted with a friendly tea tasting on the spot! This place completely lacks pretense -- it's all about the amazing teas.  I'm such a fan.

Each time I have gone back, Haymen has gone out of his way to give free tastings and free scoops of tea to take home when I buy -- and by that I mean free scoops of the really good stuff. I love places where the owner/managers are enthusiastic about their business and products -- and Aroma is definitely one of them. I ask all my questions and have learned a lot about tea from him Go!! This place is a gem.
author: Mae R.

description:
Have a hundred dollars to blow.......on tea? Even though the recessionary crunch may have you strapped for extra cash, one sip of this tea might change you mind (it did for us!). 

We found this shop from the workers of SenSpa. After a day of relaxation and drinking chocolate oolong tea, a popular drink at the spa, our masseuse directed us to see Ying at Aroma and we are so glad she did. 

As soon as you walk in, Ying offers you a seat, takes note of the kind of teas you enjoy and she brews you a small cup of fresh, piping hot loose leaf tea. The Husby and I purchased: Milk oolong, chocolate oolong (excellent with chocolate covered almonds and dried apples) and blue people (has a sweet, licorice taste to it) and $100.00 later, we were happily sipping tea; we were warm, cozy with absolutely NO buyers remorse. 

Thought I might mention that the teas can be used for approximately four cups before becoming dilute. Bonus - the tea is so fragrant and tasty, additional sugar or honey is not needed.

So, give Aroma a wiff and a swig and if you love tea, you will be hooked ;) Place is small, but their selection packs a major punch!!

Oh, and PS! Parking is a bit sketchy and there's a flock of pigeons fluttering about; don't be surprised if one comes into the shop. Adds to the experience.
author: April D.

description: I had a lovely time learning, smelling and tasting the teas here on Super Bowl Sunday!  The owner helped me pick out a wonderful, unique B Day present. I would highly recommend this shop for loose leaf teas of all kinds.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
I met the tea master, Haymen, while I was running some business errands at another shop. He overheard me asking for a particular tea that that shop didn't have and he gave me his card to check out his place.
I was surprised to find out that he offered free tea tastings daily. I'm not a tea person, but hey it's free and Haymen is quite a charming charismatic fella. 
He's definitely tea guru: he explains the effects, benefits, origins, processes, tastes, possible cocktail concoctions, etc. for every tea. He gives tips on how to properly brew tea and tells interesting anecdotes. Bottom line, he's good company and puts on quite a tea show--I've never met a person who is this passionate about tea. It makes me wonder what he's like when there is actually a group of people that come in for a "tea party." 
The inside is very vibrant--huge tea canisters all around, fancy looking tea sets and decor. And of course, a tea bar to accentuate the separate seating area.

I recall a "blue people oolong" tea he served which I thought was pretty good and a "pu-er" which he described as tasting like dirt. I'm not sure which tea(s) it was, but I was wired when I left the shop and felt a "high" well into the next night.

The teas are VERY pricey-- ranging from $10 up to $50 for 4oz, depending on the tea. I'm sure it's because they're imported straight from source and only the best loose-leaf tea you can get though. The berry tea he had did taste a lot more "fresher" than the cheap bulk packaged brand I was seeking.

I bought a Thai iced tea with boba to-go for about $2.50 (which I also got to try prior to buying it). It too, tasted much fresher and crisper than other Thai-iced teas.

Haymen is very knowledgable and passionate about tea, that, along with this deep voice is enough to lure me back here for Thai iced tea and probably more tea-tastings (even though I'm not a tea person--seriously, what do they put in that stuff!?)! I wonder if his wife is the same way too.
author: Julie K.

description: Fantastic service. Used to live in the Bay Area; when I saw an Amazon Local voucher for Aroma I snapped it up, thinking I could use it online. Alas, I discovered that isn't currently an option. But never fear, the awesome folks at Aroma quickly responded to my email inquiry, and I was able to use the voucher by placing my order over the phone. I am very pleased and will definitely be re-ordering!
author: J N.

description:
This place makes me love where I live even more!  After a little bballin' and a dirty dirty (dirty in a good way) lunch, I wanted to stop by the Aroma Tea Shop and do a little tasting after hearing so much about it from my co-worker.  Brought my roommates with me and all three of us were in for a treat!  We sat down and began to sample a few of the hundreds of teas they offer.  While enjoying the tea, the hostess was so nice and informative with us, describing the different type of teas we were drinking.  

At work, we mostly have some cheap house coffee (Peet's is long gone after the market went downhill) and I feel like it was time to drink something I little more beneficial.  After my visit here, I can't even look at another lipton tea bag.  I definitely feel a bit fancy buying high quality tea, but if you think about the cost per drink, it's sooooo worth it!

I walked out of there with a bag of Blue People Oolong.  While tasting it, the hostess said 9 out of 10 people who try it would love it.  Lets make that 10 out of 11 =D.
author: Tom Y.

description: I just can't understand how some of these snobs rate Haymen and his shop anything less than 4 stars.  His prices seem dead on, he's HILARIOUS, and will offer you test tastes of almost any tea.  I really don't think I'll buy tea anywhere else in this city
author: Ryan H.

description: This tea shop was great! The tea shop owner was very helpful and provided a tasting of many teas. Being new to tea drinking, she showed us the proper way to prepare tea and helped us to choose some great teas. The next time I'm in SF I'll definitely stop by again!
author: Jamie P.

description: As my have stated, the blue ppl oolong is the best!!!! The Pu Er is also a nice change, very earthy and gives a nice buzz. It is just nice to sit and try diff teas. A bit expensive but worth it. Splurge and buy a nice teapot. DO IT, DO IT
author: Chelsey G.

description:
We happened upon this place between browsing at Green Apple Book Store and  waiting around for friends meeting up to go to the inexpensive Sushi Buffet on opposite corner. All in all a great location.

The education and sipping experience has brought us back many times. We recommend the Puer and Blue People selections. We also refer other tea lovers to this shop all the time.

Regarding price we calculated that the amount of times that one pot can be refilled its well worth it since a small package can last up to one month.
author: Heather M.

description:
Aroma is our spot for tea, hands down.  Sit down at the tea table and explore a wide range of very fresh, seasonal teas (primarily Chinese).  The last few times we went there, we purchased the Milk Oolong, Russian Caravan Black Tea, and of course a supreme Oolong.  Ask which teas are new or fresh and they will treat you to a plentiful selection.

The very friendly husband and wife travel to-and-from Asia a few times a year to select very specific teas.  As such, much of their tea is imported and can be just a little pricey (but very worth it).  It's not uncommon for us to walk out of there with $100+ worth of tea.  For those of you that only drink the finest, Aroma has some competition grade teas as well.

You will of course have a caffeine rush when you leave.
author: Mike T.

description: I love this place! The owners are both very informative and friendly.  If you are looking for something different, this would be the place to experience something new.  Hands down, Jade Iron Goddess Tie Guan Yin and Supreme Taiwan Jin Xuan Milk Oolong have become favorite's.  I now have a separate cupboard just for exotic tea.  If you haven't experienced this place, please do!
author: Lina S.

description:
Before Teavana was the rage at suburban shopping malls, this young guy from Macau (Haymen DaLuz) was educating people about loose leaf teas. Sure, the storefront wasn't much to write home about... 

but I loved that tea service table he imported from Asia -- even the ashtrays that swing out from under the rail (and I don't even smoke!). The well-dressed Haymen was professional and not condescending as he carried out a tea tasting like it was a sophisticated wine tasting.

I appreciated the explanations about 'rinsing or washing' the leaves / herbs before you actually brew and drink. Tea has a subtle taste that is often lost on a society that chugs strong, black coffee -- so he also explained we shouldn't steep the leaves for too long. 

Ounces of loose leaf teas can add up quickly, but you can get several infusions per teaspoon if you know what you're doing. However, I fell in love with the Taiwanese milk oolong from day one -- which explains why I'm purposefully hide my wallet when I passby this boutique!
author: Sunny T.

description:
I love this place. I have never been to a tea tasting before and was very impressed with the culture involved. It really gives you a great appreciation for tea.  We were able to sample a lot of different teas as part of our tasting and learned a lot about the health benefits of specific tea varieties. The man and wife team that ran it were very knowledgeable and inviting. 

A++
author: Jenna K.

description:
he was a little weird, but the tea was super good. 
probably the best tea I've ever bought. 
Blue People Peach Oolong tea. 
I'm definitely going back for more.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
There's a special place in my heart for this shop. I went here with a girl and I'll always remember it. It was a one of those crush-filled moments when you're waiting for the first move. I made it of course. But when the dude asked me if I was paying for her tea order I said, "Nope, nope." 

It's a good place to take a date. It's even a good place to get your tea. But it's a bit overpriced and nontraditional. They know how to make tea, that's for sure. But it's a little too business oriented and non-zen for my flavor. 

But if you're looking for somewhere to purchase your Supreme Monkey Picked Oolong or whathaveyou, this is a good spot. For me, it's more nostalgia than anything. But if you go, be sure to set it up for some nostalgia of your own. Use it as a followup to a weekend lunch date...fo sho.
author: Joseph S.

description:
Yeahhhh, I'm a tea snob. 
Ever since my Aunt sent me a tea pot from Japan with a bag of Genmai cha, my addiction's only been going downhill.
But real talk. Come near me with a tea bag and I'll kick you in the face. 


My mom found this shop when wandering around Clement before work and she came home with 3 bags of tea saying, !!!!ifoundateashop!!, excitement!. Ever since then, she's been going there for tea. Mostly just to sit at the little tea bar to drink a ton of samples.

She took me there yesterday after dim sum and we had a nice time trying a bunch of herbal teas. We ended up taking a bag of Peach Passion tea home, which was a beautiful blend of black tea, passion flowers, and dried peaches. The lady also gave us a free bag of Blue People Oolong, one of our absolute favorites. (mom was like, free!tea!!!!!!) . Thoooooough, we only asked for 2 oz, the girl was like "Hey, Imma over fill this bag and then give ya'll 15 dollars worth instead of 11 dollars worth like you asked for haaaaaaaYYY". Okay, she didn't say that. But if she did, overpaying wouldn't have been a problem because I would've been too busy laughing.
author: Lindsey A.

description: Lovely teas.  Tasted the Monkey Pick Oolong (deeply fragrant and smoky) and tried the ultra-feminine Chocolate Blue People Teas.   Leaves one a super calm feeling of inner well being. Enough said.  Bought a few ounces of each said teas.  Then asked about Dragon Well's teas, and the owner (Hayman?) asked us to return next month for a fresh batch.  Definitely will!!!
author: Sheue L.

description:
This place is great! I sampled about eight kinds of herbal tea. My favorite was the lavender with pink roses and osmanthus. Very soothing.
I've been here twice. The first time other people were sampling tea, and the tea woman seemed to not know about all the herbal teas I could try. She kept bringing me tea with caffeine. The second time I was the only person in the shop and the tea woman brought me many herbal teas to try. It was a wonderful experience. I highly recommend it.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description:
The manager boy - that's whats up!!! ;)
He will hustle that tea, but sure he'll show you some good time presenting it too!
Me and my friend had a random oolong tasting outta visiting that store.
Entertaining.

Perfect shop if you looking for someone's gift since they have a variety of tea ware.
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: I love tea and so when I wandered in here with my hubby I wasn't expecting to have such a long tea tasting session with such great information about the teas we were sampling. We were so impressed with their knowledge and the presentation that we ended up buying a sample pack.
author: Petra S.

description:
I adore this shop, not only for my love of tasty oolong teas, but also because of the couple who run the store. They have a really cute family,  are always very kind to their customers, and let you try as many teas as you like. 
Great location just off of Clement - always open during the day:)
author: Sarah H.

description:
Always a party at the Aroma Tea Shop.

My friend and I decided to check out Aroma Tea Shop after a nice afternoon meal of dim sum.  The storeowner, Haymen, with a charm spliced between a mad scientist and a used car dealer, greeted us as we entered.  He sat us down at his fancy tea table and proceeded to let us sample one type of tea after another.

Haymen would grab a random bottle of green tea off the top right shelf, then go for a bottle of the black stuff from the bottom left.  He would ask us to take a whiff from each one before he dumped the leaves into a teapot.

Welcome to How to Drink Tea 101.  Class is in session.  Not before long, I learned which tea leaves needed a hotter or cooler water temperature to be steeped.  What were the origins of the leaves.  How it should taste.  Which pouring would bring out the maximum aroma of the tea.

I would recommend anybody to stop by and take a look.  Go for a free tea tasting and enjoy the experience.  Haymen won't pressure you to make a purchase.  He really seems to be enjoying what he does.  So, check it out.
author: Sam T.

description:
Awesome Entertainment, lots of great teas. Friendly atmosphere.  This is the best way to get into tea drinking...

One of the best places to take a visiting friend.
author: Jimmy L.
Ms Ayden B.

description: A great variety of tea selection and fresh to the taste. The Tea Master Haymen has got a sense of humor but don't let that fool you as he is very knowledgeable with his teas so ask away. He does FREE tea tasting and that is what got me to buy the teas as they are very aromatic and fresh. I even bought the teaware to get started. I've been a return customer after that. I really really really  like the Blue People Oolong Tea (Premium) and Green Tea. My health is looking better than ever! Try Aroma Tea Shop out if you haven't.  I would definitely recommend anyone here who wants fresh quality teas for reasonable prices. Take advantage of the free tea tasting as I did. There are a few seats so  you can always bring friends along if you do not want to go alone. No pressure in buying and you get a laugh with the Tea Master.  Oh yesss, I just found out they have a private lot for parking on the same block for customers. Look for the big sign. Hope this helps!
author: Lavender B.

description:
I never thought I would find myself in a tea shop but there we were, with the sole purpose of Christmas shopping and got a gift ourselves by finding such a great tea shop.

The woman who...man the shop (the ones in the pictures, banners, etc) is an awesome hostess.  She let us try everything, and the best thing was that her..decorum (what a word) was simply genuine.  I had never met anyone who loved tea the way she seemed to -- and she was more than knowledgeable.  

Great tea experience and the prices are... I don't know how to tell tea prices but they're definitely not cheap yet worth more than they are.

Try hoji chan, if you like the toasty flavor.  $27/4oz.  Yikes, but yum.
author: JC R.

description: Nice place. the tea is rlly good. its kinda expensive. the guy working there is really nice, and gave me a bunch of teas to try. ill def be comin back
author: Nikita K.

description: Aroma Tea Shop's rose tea was gifted to my by a friend. It has little rose buds in it and tastes incredible--soft and fragrant black tea. I also like the tea bar where you can try pretty much anything your heard desires. Not too many places like this lovely little shop.
author: katrina w.

description: WOW! This place has some GREAT customer service. We came in just as they were re-stocking their shelves and they stopped what they were doing to walk myself and friends through all kinds of selections. I was so impressed with the variety and the freshness of each tea. I cannot wait to drink everything I bought just to go back on a more convenient day for this store and try something new. This is now one of my favorite stores here in SF.
author: Jena D.

description:
This place is pretty cool.  It looks like a little hole in the wall, but you can try all kinds of teas here and then buy the ones you like!  Their specialty seems to be Blue People Oolong, which is an oolong tea with licorice root in it.  The teas are kind of pricey but, it's really an experience.

The hostess was really nice but said some people aren't nice to her when they come in.  Be nice to the hostess!
author: Jessica N.

description: Lots of great teas but they push a little hard.
author: Bryan P.

description: We love this place, we know Yang and she is very welcoming. Whenever we go to Chinatown we will visit. Cheers to ordering online when you run out of awesome green tea that promotes health like know other.
author: Lori B.

description:
I love tea and tea shops.  It's always nice to get a tasting.  Haymen is an interesting fellow.  He reminds me of a magician in terms of speech, demeanor and presentation.  Selection is good; a little bit heavier in terms of blends, flavored-teas and scents than I am particularly interested, but still a very pleasant experience overall.  

Oh, I think they also charged me sales tax on my loose leaf tea purchase; I am not certain but I am pretty sure.  It didn't occur to me until after I left the shop.  Anyway, this is a big no-no.  Loose leaf is considered to be the same as a grocery food purchase, in other words not a taxable item.  Watch out that they do not charge you sales tax, because it they do they are probably pocketing the money.  If this is the case I would consider it very dishonest and disappointing.  Based on this I am changing my rating from four to two stars.
author: daniel g.

description:
Fantastic for those who are uninitiated to tea varieties to drop in, try some of the many types and have a friendly conversation with the owner. I wandered in off the street and tried about 4-5 different types of tea and walked out with 3 of them and a free sample of another.

The difference here is that you KNOW what you are getting instead of going to another tea shop, staring at a wall of tea and walk out hoping your selection is good. For those who are knowledgeable (the reviewer teapot for example), this place may not be their speed, but for the rest of us who are not as in-the-know, this place is a real treat and learning experience. I plan to go back again and again whenever I get the taste for a new daily cup.
author: Arash A.

description:
This place is amazing.  I walked in just curious and ended up getting a 20-minute tea lesson with free tastings.  I can assure you that the reviewer who said the tea was stored in glass jars is incorrect.  Steel cans galore, except for the ornamental teas, which are so tightly wound that the tea itself is protecting the tea.

In any case, 5 stars for the proprietor who educated me and has earned my future business.
author: David O.

description:
I'm not much of a tea drinker and I'd never been to a tea shop, but I was really curious, so we checked Yelp for the best reviewed tea shop and checked it.

Another reviewer said it well...It's like a pulling up to a free wine tasting, where they educate you on the product without pressuring you to buy anything.

I especially loved how approachable and friendly the owner is. He was great at figuring out what kind of teas I'd like.

go check it out!
author: Sarah G.

description:
In this world of low-margin retail and deteriorating customer service I value personal service second only to product quality.  The Aroma Tea Shop offers both and that's why I travel there from Marin for all my tea needs.

Haymen is the heart and soul of the Aroma experience.  He welcomes all to take a seat at an attractive and comfortable marble tea bar where he presents an experience reminiscent of a sushi bar.  Haymen offers unlimited tastings of a wide selection of fresh teas, educating his audience about the source of different varieties and best preparation techniques.  His inventory spans from greens, oolong and black teas to specialty teas enhanced with fruit and spices.

As he expertly splashes potfuls of water precisely heated to the correct temperature for each variety, Haymen allows guests to compare aroma and taste of even the most expensive varieties in his inventory.  No obligation to buy, but an optional tip is encouraged for browsers.  A wide selection of clay tea pots and cups rounds out Aroma's inventory.

I time my trips to the Aroma Tea Shop to coincide with takeout visits to the Taiwan Chinese restaurant around the corner.  The resulting meal is wonderfully accompanied by a robust oolong and capped by a sweet green genmaicha.  I hope you enjoy the Aroma experience as much as i do.

(Ignore the hater review.  I suspect it's from a competitor)
author: Bennet H.

description:
So you like tea, you don't know tea until you've been here bitches!  I know more about baby tea leaves and blue peoples since visiting this place than hearing Snapple's corny comercials. 

If you're lucky Hayman will there to take you on a tea sipping euphoria and his sense of humor will keep you entertained. Not as funny as yours truly but he'll put a smile on your face.

Prices range from cheap to very expensive depending on the grade of tea you get. I love the Vanilla and Peach Oolong sooo good!
author: Spooky B.

description: Love this place. Amazing tea.  Sniff and sip before you buy.
author: Ross W.

description:
We were on the hunt for a really good tea shop, and didn't know where to find a great one (I'm from Sonoma County, my friend was up from L.A.), we had just dined at Burma SuperStar, and were enjoying coffee at Blue Danube.  Aroma popped up near the top of the list on yelp, since it's just around the corner (literally) from where we were, "why not", off we went on the 1/2 block long trek, it would have been worth miles to walk, what a GREAT find!!!! 

Hayman really knows what he's doing.  He travels to China each year to sample and purchase his merchandise personally.  He knows every tea in the shop, he asks what your tastes run to, and has no compunction directing you away from some teas, and toward something else he believes you might prefer, regardless of price.  He has amazing patience, serving any sample you want to try, as well as teaching his audience how best to prepare your tea (don't boil the water, and don't steep for too long, who knew?).  Not only knowledgeable, but incredibly entertaining.  He and his wife also own the Aroma in Chinatown. 

Even if you're not in the neighborhood, it's well worth going out of your way for great tea and a great experience.  Not only are we going back, but we've already recommended the shop to anyone who'll listen.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Let it be known that there is no shortage of tea shops in san francisco, and I have been to many of them, however I have to say that Aroma Tea Shop is the best.

The goodness begins with a really cool tasting bar (think wine tasting but tea instead) where you can taste any tea they have. Even the ultra high end ones. The owners (husband and wife I think?) are both very nice and the guy knows all there is to know about tea and will always take time to educate you on whatever it is you want to know about. 

Now if you are a suburban zombie or think that starbucks or peets is good, then you will require some re-education. But don't worry...there is hope for you if you can make it to this store.

The blue people oolong tea is perhaps the best damn tea I have ever had and has ruined me for all other teas. A must taste when you are there. Also the black teas, the chamomile and the lavender teas are all good and serve useful purposes. (staying awake or going to sleep)

Be prepared to pay between $20 and $40 for half a bag but if calculate how much you pay for one cup at crapbucks you come out ahead in the end. Plus there is no comparison......this tea is amazing.

It's a great place to kill a half hour. Taste, learn. buy, live.
author: Josh J.

description: Came here a few years ago in search of some unique teas, and it was a hit! The gentleman at the front let me taste a billion different flavors so much that I had to rush out after my purchase cuz I had to use the bathroom! LOL. Lily D pretty much explains it all as to why I gave such a high rating, to add to that the prices are reasonable! Great place to grab tea for any occassion! = )
author: Irene N.

description:
I went here after hearing that "Tea Man will can and will sell you anything."

I didn't believe my friend, but I had to check out this Tea Man he kept raving about.

Sure enough, Tea Man sold me on just about every tea and proved that I did not know anything about tea.

Don't miss this place if you're visiting the city.

The Tea Man is awesome and very entertaining.
author: Michael P.

description: Best tea experience that I have ever had. The monotone, sarcastic, lord of boiling water was a great guide. Please don't come here if you like bubbly sales people.  But if you like tea, teapots, sampling tea or sarcastic humor about foreign packaging editors please visit this shop. We will be back for sure.
author: Kennan S.

description:
I heart Ying. She completes me.
And the tea isn't bad either. Reeeally like their Yunnan and Lapsang Souchong. And their Longevity Eyebrow is so light and delicious. But you can try anything in the store. Anything. Honestly, you can stay as long as you like and taste to your hearts content. Three cheers for a free caffeine buzz!!
Hot Tip: They are getting a new shipment of teas in mid-June. mmmm....tea.
author: Sky C.

description: Whether  you are a tea snob or a newcomer to the wondrous world of tea, there is something here for everyone. The art of tea is presented to their visitors in it's true essence. If you are in a rush, this is probably not the place for you. Tea is appreciated like a fine wine at this friendly "ma and pa" establishment. They let you sample any of their teas at their beautiful tea table as they share information about what you're drinking. Their prices are reasonable, but can become pricey if you want some of the elite teas. (ie. Tieguanyin, Gyokuro) And yes they have some good ones!
author: Ant T.

description: Sampling tea with the attractive and charming proprietor makes for an entertaining afternoon.  Yummy selection of blacks, whites, greens, oolongs and herbals.
author: Ziadee C.

description: Feels like it's run by a new generation of tea shop owners.  A wide variety of white, green, black, etc. teas line the shelves, complete with humorous labels.  The owner is young, funny and laid back.  Perfect environment for exploring (fine) teas, especially if you're new to tea drinking.
author: matt k.

description: I have a friend that likes tea the way I like wine.  He was a hardcore tea drinker and introduced me to my first japanese milk teas as well as some other varietals.  Then he took me to his favorite tea shop in SF.  I was blown away by the gigantic marble table with the built in drain.  As the hot water and leaves flew through the air, I knew I was among people that really loved their tea.  I think we tasted about six or seven different teas before finally alighting on the Blue People Oolong tea.  Like the label says, "It's like a party in your mouth!"  I haven't found a place in DC to get my fix of this taiwanese tea, so I stopped in last time I was in town to pick up 4oz that should last me for a while, depending on how cold this winter gets!
author: shawn g.

description: Aroma Tea Shop is THE tea shop to go to for your tea purchase. The lady who owns the place is quiet, but very nice, and how many tea shops have you been to that let you taste ALMOST ANY tea in their store? Not that many. Be sure you go in with an empty bladder, 'cause you'll be rushing to the nearest bathroom. There's dozens of teas to choose from, all for you to try for free. YA still gotta pay for it if your buyin' it, though.
author: Evan B.

description: This little tea shop right off of Clement St is excellent! The tea is expensive, but it tastes so good, and you can steep it all at least 2-3 times. You can sample a bunch of tea while you're there, and the shopkeeper always drops an interesting little sample in your bag when you leave. I love the Blue People Oolong. Their Jasmine Pearl is excellent--I forget which one I picked up but I think it was the cheaper version. There's also a terrific herbal berry tea that I need to buy. Every other tea I've sampled has been great.
author: Tim G.

description:
Aroma Tea Shop has become an official stop on my tour of SF for visitors.  The tea tasting is top-notch and educational, but what makes the experience really special and memorable is the welcoming, laid-back and genuine-ly non-sales-y atmosphere.  I work in an office stocked with at least 20 varieties of gourmet, loose-leaf teas yet still find myself buying my own from Aroma because I can't help but want to be a part of their business doing well.

I can't speak on their prices because I haven't shopped around, but with Aroma Tea Shop, your tea comes with the fun of Hayman's company and for most, it'll be more than worth the difference.
author: Tina H.

description: Wonderful experience. The owner sat down with my wife and I and explained how each tea is made and allowed us to sample many of the teas in his shop. He was extremely informative, easy to talk to and had a great sense of humor. Could not ask for a better experience. Oh, and the teas we purchased were the best I have had. He even threw in some free samples with our order. I am ordering more tea from their web site now.
author: Dave P.

description: Can't say enough nice things about the informative, charming people who work in and own this tea shop. They have it set up in a way where you can do copious tastings, ask all the questions you want, walk away warmed up, caffeineated (if you choose teas that have caffeine) and with arm loads of tasty rarities. (No pun intended "rare-it-teas.") There's plenty of tea to choose from, sweet and fruity to earthy, bitter or floral, luxury to affordable, local, Chinese, Japanese, etc. A SF gem.
author: Lorae K.

description: Love love love. Everything other yelpers said - great way to spend an hour learning about and tasting amazing teas!
author: Kathleen V.

description: Rainy day, freezing cold, no umbrella, let's have a cup of tea. This store was almost calling us....coooome....coooooooome. Ok! We go in, we get a seat and we are definitely overloaded of infos, tasting at least 10 different teas and also given a little show by the owner who for sure knows how to sell. I must say that sometimes the guy was too fast and cloudy, but since i am 101 for tea tasting I think I had a good introduction to it. We got out really warm, with some good leaves and with something to remember.
author: Dario B.

description: I was out of my favorite green tea and happened to be across the street at Green Apple so I decided to pop in here quick for a purchase. I was expecting just a store.. not a tasting room.   The best way to describe this place is imagine going up to Sonoma for some wine tasting.. except it's in the inner richmond and it's tea instead of wine.  The host, Haymen, is so fun to listen to.  I really don't know much about tea but he spent 30 minutes with me letting me taste different kinds and teaching me about it.   This was such a great experience, and i love the tea.  I'm definitily bringing some friends here.
author: kimberly k.

description: I walked in just looking for something cool to do on my visit to SF and now I have tea parties. That's right, I'm a grown man having tea parties cause of this place.
author: Daniel B.

description: I think "teapot"  fails to understand that charisma and friendliness are good things, and people are willing to spend a little extra for them.  if you want wholesale tea prices, find a place on the web and buy.  If you want to learn about chinese tea from a charismatic and friendly guy, go to Aroma and let Hayman give you the full tasting experience.  You will buy tea not because he is nice, but because the experience is eye-opening and enjoyable.
author: Sam K.

description:
I was sadly let-down by this little shop.  Squeezed amongst the day markets, Cantonese-style cafes, and medicine shops, Aroma seems like it would be a safe bet when trying to locate quality tea and a knowledgeable staff.  However, in a city of wonderful tea shops, this one is greatly lacking.  
  Aroma is an odd collection of overpriced, low quality teas that are poorly stored (glass jars are a "No No" as tea goes stale in about a week if stored this way).  What all of this means is a nasty taste left in my mouth.  The only saving grace they had was that they were less offensive than the Vital Tea stores on Chinatown (no barking salesmen, yet one does still feel like they are being sold a used car).  Beyond that, I feel that their staff are somewhat more interested in making money off of tea than making a tasty cup and lasting customers.
  I've been here several times in an attempt to see if any change for the better has occurred and, alas, nothing has come of it.  Sadly, a "meh" sort of tea shop with "meh" sort of tea.
author: Scott N.

description: Very nice woman working at the counter. Great prices, and they frequently throw in extra free samples whenever I buy any tea. Also the more you shop there, the more they hook you up with freebies. Did I forget to mention free delicious tea tasting? Taste any and every tea before you buy if you want. I highly recommend this place!
author: Jonathan H.

description: I assume this place is pretty new, since I'm an avid tea fan and only discovered it (lol). It's got great tea and fun events at great prices, in a cozy atmosphere. Love it!
author: Jane D.

description:
an amazing place to find and taste great teas.
note that these are mainly chinese teas (not japanese).
the owner was the friendliest and most helpful I've seen. gave me to taste many different types of teas till I found those I like. adding interesting information.
I will definitely come back again!
author: Saflul m.

description: I've been coming here for years.  Hayman is a fantastic host and tea-educator, and a fun guy.  The shop stocks great teas, suited to whatever your taste, and the tea-tasting is definitely a pleaser!  Highly recommended...
author: D. B.

description: Finding this place was serendipitous. I was just thinking to myself that  I wanted to learn more about loose leaf tea and the first thing that caught my eye was Aroma Tea Shop. The owner walked me through the different types of tea, their unique qualities, and their health benefits. I tried everything from Oolong to Black and walked out with a traditional green tea and a Oolong tea with Ginsing unlike anything I've ever had before. Just a few weeks later, and I have bought myself a cast iron tea pot and cups, and make tea every morning before work. Being an avid coffee drinker, that's saying a lot!
author: Cat S.

description: Haymen the tea master is wonderful in explaining and exploring the process of tea drinking. I especially like the smelling cups and trying all the different flavors.
author: sammy l.

description: I took some of my aspiring tea-snob friends here for the free tasting, and we were very pleasantly surprised.  We'd each done plenty of tea-tasting in similar shops in China, and were impressed by the owner's charisma and able to turn a tea tasting into a great after-dinner show.  He was also quite generous with his tea, so it's a great place to go if you're still trying to figure out what you like.  If you don't want to buy tea, you don't have to -- I didn't feel pressured at all.  As to price, well... I guess I'm used to paying extraordinary sums of money for rather pedestrian drinks, so it didn't bother me to pay $14 for about 1 months' worth of pretty good tea.  Thanks, Starbucks!
author: Katharine N.

description:
they have a tea bar with a proprietor who is passionate about tea and will pour you many free tastes of the extensive selection of teas they have.  great selection of green teas, pu-erhs, flavored teas, flower teas, medicinal teas, monkey-picked teas and a variety of tea accoutrement.  you can buy tea in 2oz and 4oz vaccuum-sealed bags and he'll also give you 1oz ones you can take home to try.  

definately worth stopping by to check out.    there is another location on polk st (or did he say post) that also serves a variety of the teas iced.

and the refreshing thing about this place is the hipsters haven't found it yet!
author: X X.

description: I love this place. They have a good selection of teas and they are very helpful in picking out the right tea for your tastes and your health. They will also do tastings for you and teach you the best way to make tea.
author: David T.

description: My wife and I enjoyed this experience very much. I don't live near by, but I know that each time I'm in The City, I'll be sure to visit and sample the wonderful teas here. The place is small, it isn't fancy, but it is classy. Hundreds of teas to sample - for free! Hostess was very friendly, efficient, and knowledgeable. If you are a tea drinker, don't miss Aroma Tea Shop.
author: Basil R.

description: THIS PLACE RULES! The guy who runs the place is so cool, funny and has a great personality. Bring a date here and sit down for a tea tasting. My favorites are the Golden Lion Oolong, and the Thai Tea so far... you can't go wrong here as you can taste any tea before you buy it.
author: Dre D.

description: If you like tea, but do not like being ripped off nor convincecd of the authenticity of items by salespeople who are not from the culture that they purport to be so knowledgable regarding; then Aroma is the joint for you! Haymen (Owner-sp?) is exceptionally knowledgable about his Taiwanese Oolongs (try the blue people or Supreme Jin Xuan), and his dry sense of straight foreward humor is a youthful breath of fresh air in a world of geriatric sales ploys. Great tea, wonderful service, supreme health and vigor will all be your allies resulting from an alliance with such a venue. I am proud to say that I was (without request of my own), offered a 'Tea master,' shirt, but had to respectfully decline due to my massive pecks and inabiliy of any reasonably sized shirt to contain them: what, I'm just sayin?! Truthfully, if they were to ever put a strobe light up at Aroma, I strongly consider clubbing there...its way cheaper to fine drink fine tea, than it ever is to drink crappy alcohol, anyway!
author: Zizzle f.

description: wow.  just wow.  amazing selection, ridiculous service, and you've got to love the fact you can sample anything and everything.
author: Blake M.

description: I stumbled upon the Aroma Tea Shop with a friend one day.  We ended up staying for quite a while and spending quite a bit of cash!  It's a fun find run by a darling young couple.  Definitely something unique to share with the out-of-town crowd.
author: Bridget T.

description: Very very cool.  A thorough tea tasting of all kinds of different teas, and you really learn how to approach teas from all kinds of different angles.  I'm not a "tea person" and I loved it.
author: Carrie L.

description: This place is awesome.  The husband and wife team really do a great job. You always get to taste and learn about new and interesting teas.
author: Kathleen Y.

description: I have more tea from Aroma than I can ever drink, and I'm going back for more.  I love this store.  The couple that runs it are truly nice people, and they are generous with the free tea tastings.  They have an amazing selection of teas, mostly Chinese, but some Taiwanese as well.  Do a tea tasting...you won't be able to resist buying something.
author: Melissa G.

description: Love this store - amazing tea - if you buy stuff you can try a whole bunch.  There is nothing better than quality tea leaves.  And the folks at Aroma are friendly and help you find the tea that you'll like the best.
author: David B.

description:
I wandered into this shop on a Friday at the end of a very long week. A nice man immediately started offering me fresh brewed teas, what more can one ask for? The tea was served in minuscule "shot" teacups, very fun to drink out of. It was prepared on a round stone counter top that had a faucet on one side...hard to explain, you will just have to see it for yourself! It is a small store, large jars of quality teas are artfully displayed, and two small, sculpted wood tea tables inhabit the window view. They also carry an elegant selection of Chinese teapots.
I will be back in here for sure. This store happens to be in a fantastic neighborhood...OK I'm biased.
author: Lesley S.

description: I was on the fence between a 4 and 5, but I gave them a 5 mostly because I gave Vital Tea a 5, and this place is really just as good. The owner's entertainment style is more subtle, but he is a funny and sharp guy. And he may not have 50 years of expert knowledge like some people in the city, but give him another 10 years and he will be the wise one in town. And at his age, he is certainly at the top of his peer group. Prices are decent; some things are cheaper here and some are more expensive. But this place is definitely worth going to for anyone with a taste for tea.
author: Ian S.

description: The presentation and tea tasting is ideal for learning about the difference in types and categories of teas.  It reminds me of one of those places where people on "Blind Date" would go, just so there's some interaction and activity.  I sampled lots of different teas ranging from herbal to green to black to fruity rose bud and lychee.  The owner is very knowledgeable about his product and shows great enthusiasm towards educating and answering questions.
author: Jason F.

description: I was attracted by their banner advertising free tea samples. I was in for a treat. My wife and I wandered in not knowing what to expect. Our host was not only generous with the tea but he was also charismatic and informative. It's like going to Tea 101. For instance, I didn't know green tea had to be made at 140F and not at boiling temperature. There was no pressure to buy the tea even though I've had about 10 different samples. It was like going to a wine tasting event but you get to try tea instead. There is one tea that he offers and you have to drink it like a shot. Their prices for their tea mug are on the high side. It was priced around $8 and I was able to find the same one at Super Tokio for about $3-4. I'd go here for the tea experience and decide if I want to purchase anything later. I'm no tea expert so I can't tell if the teas were reasonably priced or if they were of higher quality. We did end up buying about $50 of tea.
author: Armstrong B.

description: fun, fun, fun. easy to walk out with $75 worth of tea, but the owner and his adorable family throw in all sorts of extra samples making it a good deal.  an extremely enjoyable experience all around.
author: Julia H.

description:
with the exeption of a small few, i am not sure about other reviewers...it seems like many call themselves self professed tea connaisseurs after their first tasting. I have been buying finer Chinese teas for years and still have a lot to learn.
I enjoyed the tea bar, i will even go as far as to say some of the teas are ok...I purchased 2 of the most popular teas from China, one green: a Dragon well (good but a bit pricey) and a Pu'erh. For those in the know, the dark fermented tea known as Pu'erh is the Bordeaux of red wines. It is popular, prized, and often sold in "cakes" and can fetch $$$. Much of the Pu'erh on the market is "counterfitted"...what is true about Cuban cigars from the Mexican border is true about Pu'erh. They suggested a few cakes, and I settled on a $50 cake based on their recommendations, which should buy you a nice cake. I think you understand what i am driving at here, but when I first brewed it, it had a fishy taste, no smoky/marshmellowy taste which is characteristic of this tea, and found straw in it. When one pays this kind of $ for a cake, you have to rely on the seller, who should be buying from a reputable dealer. In fairness to them, maybe they did not know what they had but I guess I will never know, and will always wonder. What I do know is that other retailers of Pu'erh (i will not name their competitors, there are only 2 in SF) have always sold me good cakes, and go through great lengths to make sure they are good. 
On the up side, they do have a nice collection of clay pots at reasonable prices. 
BTW, this Blue People is ok,...to each his own, but again have to wonder why it's so popular there...it has a slight taste of Anis
author: christian i.
